results.question: What is the oxidation state of phosphorus in phosphine?
results.llm_output:
In phosphine, \(\mathrm{PH_3}\), the molecule is neutral, so the sum of the oxidation states of all atoms must be zero.

1. Hydrogen is less electronegative than phosphorus, therefore each hydrogen atom is assigned an oxidation state of \(+1\).
2. Let the oxidation state of phosphorus be \(x\).

\[
x + 3(+1) = 0 \quad\Longrightarrow\quad x + 3 = 0 \quad\Longrightarrow\quad x = -3
\]

Thus, the oxidation state of phosphorus in phosphine is  

\[
\boxed{-3}
\]

results.question: Assume all processes take place at \pu{298 K}. The enthalpy change of formation of \ce{CH4(g)} is \pu{-74.8 kJ mol^{-1}}, of \ce{CO2(g)} is \pu{-393.5 kJ mol^{-1}} and it is \pu{-285.8 kJ mol^{-1}} for \ce{H2O(l)}. What is the enthalpy change for the reaction \ce{CH4(g) + 2H2O(l) -> CO2(g) + 4H2(g)} in \pu{kJ mol^{-1}}?
results.llm_output:
The enthalpy change for a reaction is obtained from the standard enthalpies of formation:

\[
\Delta H_{\text{rxn}} = \sum \nu_i \Delta H_f^\circ (\text{products})-\sum \nu_i \Delta H_f^\circ (\text{reactants})
\]

For  

\[
\ce{CH4(g) + 2H2O(l) -> CO2(g) + 4H2(g)}
\]

the standard enthalpies of formation are  

\[
\Delta H_f^\circ(\ce{CH4(g)}) = -74.8\;\text{kJ mol}^{-1},\quad
\Delta H_f^\circ(\ce{CO2(g)}) = -393.5\;\text{kJ mol}^{-1},
\]
\[
\Delta H_f^\circ(\ce{H2O(l)}) = -285.8\;\text{kJ mol}^{-1},\quad
\Delta H_f^\circ(\ce{H2(g)}) = 0\;\text{kJ mol}^{-1}.
\]

\[
\begin{aligned}
\sum \nu_i \Delta H_f^\circ (\text{products}) &= (-393.5) + 4(0) = -393.5\;\text{kJ mol}^{-1},\\[4pt]
\sum \nu_i \Delta H_f^\circ (\text{reactants}) &= (-74.8) + 2(-285.8) = -74.8 - 571.6 = -646.4\;\text{kJ mol}^{-1}.
\end{aligned}
\]

Hence

\[
\Delta H_{\text{rxn}} = -393.5 - (-646.4) = 252.9\;\text{kJ mol}^{-1}.
\]

\[
\boxed{252.9}\ \text{kJ mol}^{-1}
\]

results.question: The concentration of \ce{CO2} in a \pu{250 cm^{3}} can of fizzy drink was found to be \pu{0.099 mol dm^{-3}}. What is, in grams, the mass of \ce{CO2} dissolved in a \pu{250 cm^{3}} can of fizzy drink?
results.llm_output:
The amount of \(\ce{CO2}\) present is obtained from the concentration‑volume relation  

\[
n=\;c\times V
\]

where  

\[
c = 0.099\;\text{mol dm}^{-3},\qquad 
V = 250\ \text{cm}^{3}=0.250\ \text{dm}^{3}
\]

\[
n = 0.099\;\text{mol dm}^{-3}\times 0.250\ \text{dm}^{3}=2.475\times10^{-2}\ \text{mol}
\]

The molar mass of carbon dioxide is  

\[
M_{\ce{CO2}} = 12.01\ \text{g mol}^{-1}+2(16.00\ \text{g mol}^{-1}) = 44.01\ \text{g mol}^{-1}
\]

Hence the mass of \(\ce{CO2}\) dissolved is  

\[
m = nM = (2.475\times10^{-2}\ \text{mol})(44.01\ \text{g mol}^{-1})
      \approx 1.1\ \text{g}
\]

\[
\boxed{1.1}\ \text{g}
\]

results.question: If ten tonnes of Ambrox (\ce{C16H28O}) are produced every year, what is the number of moles produced per year?
results.llm_output:
The molar mass of Ambrox \(\ce{C_{16}H_{28}O}\) is  

\[
M = 16(12.01) + 28(1.008) + 16.00 \approx 236.4\ \text{g mol}^{-1}.
\]

Ten tonnes correspond to  

\[
10\ \text{t} = 10 \times 10^{3}\ \text{kg}=10 \times 10^{6}\ \text{g}=1.0\times10^{7}\ \text{g}.
\]

Hence the number of moles produced per year is  

\[
n = \frac{1.0\times10^{7}\ \text{g}}{236.4\ \text{g mol}^{-1}}
   \approx 4.2\times10^{4}\ \text{mol}.
\]

\[
\boxed{4.2\times10^{4}\ \text{mol}}
\]

results.question: The average bond enthalpy of \ce{C-C} is \pu{347 kJ mol^{-1}}, \ce{C-H} is \pu{413 kJ mol^{-1}}, \ce{O=O} is \pu{498 kJ mol^{-1}}, \ce{C-O} is \pu{358 kJ mol^{-1}}, \ce{C=O} is \pu{805 kJ mol^{-1}} and \ce{O-H} is \pu{464 kJ mol^{-1}}. What is the enthalpy of combustion of an isomer of octane in \pu{kJ mol^{-1}}?
results.llm_output:
The combustion of any octane isomer can be written as  

\[
\ce{C8H18 + \tfrac{25}{2} O2 -> 8 CO2 + 9 H2O}
\]

For an alkane \( \ce{C_nH_{2n+2}} \) the numbers of bonds are  

\[
\text{C–C bonds}=n-1,\qquad \text{C–H bonds}=2n+2
\]

Hence for \( \ce{C8H18} \)  

\[
\begin{aligned}
\text{C–C bonds}&=7\\
\text{C–H bonds}&=18
\end{aligned}
\]

**Bonds broken**

\[
\begin{aligned}
7\,(\text{C–C}) &=7\times 347=2429\;\text{kJ}\\
18\,(\text{C–H}) &=18\times 413=7434\;\text{kJ}\\
\frac{25}{2}\,(\text{O=O}) &=12.5\times 498=6225\;\text{kJ}
\end{aligned}
\]

Total broken \(=2429+7434+6225=16088\;\text{kJ}\)

**Bonds formed**

\[
\begin{aligned}
8\,\text{CO}_2 &:8\times 2=16\;(\text{C=O})\\
9\,\text{H}_2\text{O} &:9\times 2=18\;(\text{O–H})\\[4pt]
16\,(\text{C=O}) &=16\times 805=12880\;\text{kJ}\\
18\,(\text{O–H}) &=18\times 464=8352\;\text{kJ}
\end{aligned}
\]

Total formed \(=12880+8352=21232\;\text{kJ}\)

**Enthalpy of combustion**

\[
\Delta H_{\text{comb}} \approx \sum\text{(bonds broken)}-\sum\text{(bonds formed)}
=16088-21232=-5144\;\text{kJ mol}^{-1}
\]

\[
\boxed{-5144\ \text{kJ mol}^{-1}}
\]

results.question: EDTA reacts with copper ions according to the equation \ce{Cu^{2+} + EDTA4_{(aq)} -> [CuEDTA]^{2-}_{(aq)}}. The end-point of the titration was determined using an indicator called murexide, and it was found that \pu{0.1 g} of X required \pu{21.70 cm^{3}} of \pu{0.02 mol dm^{-3}} EDTA solution for complete reaction. What is the percent by mass of copper in compound X?
results.llm_output:
The moles of EDTA that reacted are  

\[
n_{\text{EDTA}} = M_{\text{EDTA}}\;V = 0.02\;\text{mol dm}^{-3}\times 0.02170\;\text{dm}^{3}
               = 4.34\times10^{-4}\;\text{mol}.
\]

The complex forms in a 1 : 1 stoichiometry, so the moles of copper in the sample are the same:

\[
n_{\text{Cu}^{2+}} = 4.34\times10^{-4}\;\text{mol}.
\]

Mass of copper  

\[
m_{\text{Cu}} = n_{\text{Cu}^{2+}}\;M_{\text{Cu}}
               = 4.34\times10^{-4}\;\text{mol}\times 63.55\;\text{g mol}^{-1}
               \approx 2.76\times10^{-2}\;\text{g}.
\]

The percentage of copper in the 0.10 g sample is  

\[
\% \text{Cu}= \frac{m_{\text{Cu}}}{m_{\text{sample}}}\times 100
            = \frac{2.76\times10^{-2}\;\text{g}}{0.10\;\text{g}}\times 100
            \approx 27.6\%.
\]

\[
\boxed{27.6\%}
\]

results.question: The dissolved \ce{CO2} in fizzy drinks is in equilibrium with a small quantity of gaseous \ce{CO2} at the top of the sealed container. The Henry's law constant for \ce{CO2} is \pu{0.033 mol dm^{-3} atm^{-1}}. The partial pressure of \ce{CO2} gas in a \pu{250 cm^{3}} can of fizzy drink is \pu{3 atm} at \pu{25 deg C}. What is the the concentration of \ce{CO2} in the fizzy drink in \pu{mol dm^{-3}}?
results.llm_output:
The Henry’s law expression is  

\[
C = k_{\mathrm H}\,P
\]

where  

- \(k_{\mathrm H}=0.033\;\text{mol dm}^{-3}\,\text{atm}^{-1}\)  
- \(P=3\;\text{atm}\)

Thus  

\[
C = 0.033\;\frac{\text{mol}}{\text{dm}^{3}\,\text{atm}}\times 3\;\text{atm}
   = 0.099\;\text{mol dm}^{-3}
\]

\[
\boxed{0.099}\ \text{mol dm}^{-3}
\]

results.question: In the reaction \ce{CO + H2O <=> CO2 + H2}, an initial mixture of \pu{40 mol} of \ce{CO}, \pu{20 mol} of \ce{H2}, and \pu{20 mol} of \ce{CO2} in contact with \pu{40 mol} of steam was allowed to come to equilibrium in a reactor at \pu{1100 K}. At \pu{1100 K} this reaction has a $K_p$ of 0.64. What is the number of moles of \ce{CO} leaving the reactor after equilibration?
results.llm_output:
The reaction  

\[
\ce{CO + H2O <=> CO2 + H2}
\]

has an extent \(x\) (mol) toward the products.  

\[
\begin{aligned}
n_{\ce{CO}} &= 40 - x\\
n_{\ce{H2O}} &= 40 - x\\
n_{\ce{CO2}} &= 20 + x\\
n_{\ce{H2}} &= 20 + x
\end{aligned}
\]

The total number of moles remains constant:

\[
n_{\text{tot}} = (40-x)+(40-x)+(20+x)+(20+x)=120 .
\]

For an ideal‑gas mixture the equilibrium constant expressed in terms of mole fractions is  

\[
K_p = \frac{y_{\ce{CO2}}\,y_{\ce{H2}}}{y_{\ce{CO}}\,y_{\ce{H2O}}}
      =\frac{\left(\dfrac{20+x}{120}\right)^2}
             {\left(\dfrac{40-x}{120}\right)^2}
      =\left(\frac{20+x}{40-x}\right)^{2}.
\]

Given \(K_p = 0.64\),

\[
\left(\frac{20+x}{40-x}\right)^{2}=0.64\quad\Longrightarrow\quad
\frac{20+x}{40-x}= \sqrt{0.64}=0.8 .
\]

Solve for \(x\):

\[
20+x = 0.8(40-x)=32-0.8x \\
1.8x = 12 \;\Longrightarrow\; x = \frac{12}{1.8}=6.67\text{ mol}.
\]

Thus \(6.67\) mol of \(\ce{CO}\) react (leave the reactor) at equilibrium.

\[
\boxed{6.67}\ \text{mol}
\]

results.question: The enthalpy change of formation of \ce{H2O(l)} is \pu{-285.8 kJ mol^{-1}}. What is the enthalpy change for the overall cell reaction during electrolysis of water, \ce{2H2O(l) -> 2H2(g) + O2(g)} in \pu{kJ mol^{-1}}?
results.llm_output:
The reaction enthalpy is obtained from the standard enthalpies of formation:

\[
\Delta H_{\text{rxn}} = \sum \nu_i \Delta H_f^\circ(\text{products})-\sum \nu_i \Delta H_f^\circ(\text{reactants})
\]

Products: \(2\;\ce{H2(g)}\) and \(\ce{O2(g)}\) \(\Rightarrow\) \(\Delta H_f^\circ =0\).

Reactants: \(2\;\ce{H2O(l)}\) \(\Rightarrow\) \(\Delta H_f^\circ =2(-285.8\;\text{kJ mol}^{-1}) = -571.6\;\text{kJ}\).

\[
\Delta H_{\text{rxn}} = 0 - (-571.6\;\text{kJ}) = +571.6\;\text{kJ}
\]

Hence, the overall cell reaction during the electrolysis of water has anpy change of  

\[
\boxed{571.6}\ \text{kJ mol}^{-1}
\]

results.question: A standard small bag typically contains \pu{22 g} of a snack. When a \pu{2.0 g} sample of the snack is completely burned, it results in a temperature rise of \pu{20.9 deg C} in \pu{500 g} of water within the calorimeter. The specific heat capacity of water is \pu{4.18 J K^{-1} g^{-1}}, and the conversion factor from kilojoules (kJ) to dietary calories is 0.239. What is the dietary calories content in a standard small bag of the snack?
results.llm_output:
The heat absorbed by the water is  

\[
q = m_{\text{water}}\,c_{\text{water}}\,\Delta T
   = (500\ \text{g})(4.18\ \frac{\text{J}}{\text{g·K}})(20.9\ \text{K})
   = 4.37\times 10^{4}\ \text{J}=43.7\ \text{kJ}
\]

This corresponds to the combustion of the \(2.0\ \text{g}\) sample, so the energy per gram of snack is  

\[
\frac{43.7\ \text{kJ}}{2.0\ \text{g}} = 21.9\ \frac{\text{kJ}}{\text{g}}
\]

For a standard small bag containing \(22\ \text{g}\),

\[
E_{\text{bag}} = 21.9\ \frac{\text{kJ}}{\text{g}}\times 22\ \text{g}=4.81\times10^{2}\ \text{kJ}
\]

Converting to dietary calories (1 kJ = 0.239 Cal),

\[
\text{Calories}_{\text{bag}} = 4.81\times10^{2}\ \text{kJ}\times0.239\ \frac{\text{Cal}}{\text{kJ}}
                              \approx 1.15\times10^{2}\ \text{Cal}
\]

\[
\boxed{115}\ \text{Cal}
\]

results.question: The density of liquid hydrogen is \pu{0.071 g cm^{-3}}. What is the number of moles of hydrogen molecules in \pu{1 dm^{3}} of liquid hydrogen?
results.llm_output:
The mass of liquid hydrogen in \(1\ \text{dm}^{3}\) (which equals \(1000\ \text{cm}^{3}\)) is  

\[
m = \rho V = 0.071\ \frac{\text{g}}{\text{cm}^3}\times 1000\ \text{cm}^3 = 71\ \text{g}.
\]

The molar mass of molecular hydrogen \(\text{H}_2\) is  

\[
M(\text{H}_2) = 2.016\ \frac{\text{g}}{\text{mol}}.
\]

Hence the number of moles is  

\[
n = \frac{m}{M} = \frac{71\ \text{g}}{2.016\ \text{g mol}^{-1}} \approx 35.2\ \text{mol}.
\]

\[
\boxed{35.2}\ \text{mol}
\]

\end{aligned}
\]

\[
n_{\mathrm{KOH}} = C_{\mathrm{KOH}}\;V_{\mathrm{KOH}}
               = (0.04\ \mathrm{mol\ L^{-1}})(0.00681\ \mathrm{L})
               = 2.724\times10^{-4}\ \mathrm{mol}
\]

\[
n_{\text{polymer chains}} = n_{\mathrm{KOH}} = 2.724\times10^{-4}\ \text{mol}
\]

**2. Average molar mass of the polymer chains**

\[
M_{\text{avg}} = \frac{m}{n_{\text{polymer chains}}}

               = 5.95\times10^{2}\ \mathrm{g\ mol^{-1}}
\]

\]"""

                    {(8.314\ \text{J mol}^{-1}\!\text{K}^{-1})(294\ \text{K})}
             \approx 7.3\times10^{-5}\ \text{mol}.
\]

Assuming the stoichiometry that one mole of lactic acid (\(\ce{C3H6O3}\)) yields one mole of \(\ce{CO2}\),

\[
\text{mass of lactic acid}= n_{\ce{CO2}}\times M_{\ce{C3H6O3}}
= (7.3\times10^{-5}\ \text{mol})(90.08\ \text{g mol}^{-1})
\approx 6.6\times10^{-3}\ \text{g}.
\]

\[
\boxed{6.6\times10^{-3}\ \text{g}}
\]"""

Model's final answer: 6.6x10^{-3}\g

Correct answer: 0.0198

Judgement:

results.question: When fuel gases are supplied under the same pressure, the heat released per second in a burner is directly proportional to standard enthalpy change of combustion and inversely proportional to the square root of relative molecular mass. Assume hydrogen and methane are supplied under the same pressure. The heat released with \ce{H2} is \pu{-285.8 kJ mol^{-1}} and the heat released with \ce{CH4} is \pu{-890.3 kJ mol^{-1}}. What is the ratio of heat released per second in a burner fuelled by hydrogen compared to in the same burner fuelled by methane?
results.llm_output:
The heat‑release rate in the burner is

\[
\dot Q \propto \frac{|\Delta H_{\text{comb}}|}{\sqrt{M}}
\]

Hence for hydrogen (\(\mathrm{H_2}\)) and methane (\(\mathrm{CH_4}\))

\[
\frac{\dot Q_{\mathrm{H_2}}}{\dot Q_{\mathrm{CH_4}}}
=
\frac{|\Delta H_{\mathrm{H_2}}|}{\sqrt{M_{\mathrm{H_2}}}}
\Big/
\frac{|\Delta H_{\mathrm{CH_4}}|}{\sqrt{M_{\mathrm{CH_4}}}}
=
\frac{|\Delta H_{\mathrm{H_2}}|}{|\Delta H_{\mathrm{CH_4}}|}
\frac{\sqrt{M_{\mathrm{CH_4}}}}{\sqrt{M_{\mathrm{H_2}}}} .
\]

Using the given data  

\[
|\Delta H_{\mathrm{H_2}}| = 285.8\ \text{kJ mol}^{-1},\qquad 
|\Delta H_{\mathrm{CH_4}}| = 890.3\ \text{kJ mol}^{-1},
\]
\[
M_{\mathrm{H_2}} = 2\ \text{g mol}^{-1},\qquad 
M_{\mathrm{CH_4}} = 16\ \text{g mol}^{-1},
\]

\[
\frac{\dot Q_{\mathrm{H_2}}}{\dot Q_{\mathrm{CH_4}}}
= \frac{285.8}{890.3}\,
\frac{\sqrt{16}}{\sqrt{2}}
= 0.321\;\times\;2.828
\approx 0.91 .
\]

\[
\boxed{0.91}
\]

results.question: The density of pure water is \pu{1 g cm^{-3}}, the melting point of pure water is \pu{273 K} and the standard enthalpy change of melting for pure water is \pu{6.01 kJ mol^{-1}}. The depression in freezing point can be calculated by $ rac{nRT_\mathrm{melt}^2}{\Delta H_\mathrm{melt}}$, where $n$ is the amount of substance (in \pu{mol}) of ions, $R$ is the gas constant, $T_\mathrm{melt}$ is the melting point of pure water, and $\Delta H_\mathrm{melt}$ is the standard enthalpy change of melting for pure water. What is the freezing point of a \pu{3 mol dm^{-3}} solution of sodium chloride in \pu{K}?
results.llm_output:
The freezing‑point depression for an electrolyte solution is  

\[
\Delta T_{\text f}= i\,K_{\text f}\,m,
\]

where  

* \(i\) = van ’t Hoff factor (for NaCl, \(i =2\)),  
* \(K_{\text f}= \dfrac{R\,T_{\text{melt}}^{2}M_{\text w}}{\Delta H_{\text{melt}}}\) is the cryoscopic constant of water,  
* \(m\) = molality of the solute (mol kg\(^{-1}\)),  
* \(M_{\text w}=18.015\;\text{g mol}^{-1}=0.018015\;\text{kg mol}^{-1}\).

---

### 1. Cryoscopic constant of water  

\[
\begin{aligned}
K_{\text f}&=\frac{(8.314\;\text{J mol}^{-1}\text{K}^{-1})(273\;\text{K})^{2}(0.018015\;\text{kg mol}^{-1})}
{6.01\times10^{3}\;\text{J mol}^{-1}}  \\
&=\frac{8.314\times 74529 \times 0.018015}{6010} \\
&\approx 1.86\;\text{K kg mol}^{-1}.
\end{aligned}
\]

---

### 2. Molality of the NaCl solution  

The solution is \(3\;\text{mol dm}^{-3}\) and the density of water is \(1\;\text{g cm}^{-3}=1\;\text{kg dm}^{-3}\).  
Thus, in 1 L (1 dm³) of solution the mass of water is essentially \(1\;\text{kg}\).

\[
m = \frac{3\;\text{mol}}{1\;\text{kg}} = 3\;\text{mol kg}^{-1}.
\]

---

### 3. Freezing‑point depression  

\[
\Delta T_{\text f}= i\,K_{\text f}\,m = 2 \times 1.86\;\text{K kg mol}^{-1}\times 3\;\text{mol kg}^{-1}
\approx 11.2\;\text{K}.
\]

---

### 4. Freezing point of the solution  

\[
T_{\text{freeze}} = T_{\text{melt}} - \Delta T_{\text f}
= 273\;\text{K} - 11.2\;\text{K}
\approx 262\;\text{K}.
\]

\[
\boxed{262\ \text{K}}
\]

results.question: The reaction for the explosion of TNT is \ce{C7H5N3O6 -> 3CO + 3C + CO2 + 1.5H2 + 1.5N2 + H2O}. What the mass (in \pu{g}) of TNT that will explode to produce \pu{1.0 dm^{3}} of gas at room temperature and pressure, assuming that the molar volume of any gas is \pu{24 dm^{3}} at RTP?
results.llm_output:
The reaction shows that each mole of TNT (\(\ce{C7H5N3O6}\)) yields the following gaseous products  

\[
\;\ce{CO} + 1\;\ce{CO2} + 1.5\;\ce{H2} + 1.5\;\ce{N2}
\]

Hence the total number of moles of gas produced per mole of TNT is  

\[
n_{\text{gas}} = 3 + 1 + 1.5 + 1.5 = 7\;\text{mol gas·mol}^{-1}\,\text{TNT}
\]

At room temperature and pressure (RTP) the molar volume of any gas is  

\[
V_{\mathrm{m}} = 24\ \text{dm}^{3}\,\text{mol}^{-1}
\]

Therefore one mole of TNT gives  

\[
V_{\text{gas per mol TNT}} = 7\,V_{\mathrm{m}} = 7 \times 24 = 168\ \text{dm}^{3}
\]

To obtain \(V = 1.0\ \text{dm}^{3}\) of gas, the required amount of TNT is  

\[
n_{\text{TNT}} = \frac{V}{V_{\text{gas per mol TNT}}}= \frac{1.0}{168}=5.95\times10^{-3}\ \text{mol}
\]

The molar mass of TNT is  

\[
M_{\text{TNT}} = 7(12.011)+5(1.008)+3(14.007)+6(15.999)=227\ \text{g mol}^{-1}
\]

Thus the mass of TNT needed is  

\[
m = n_{\text{TNT}}\;M_{\text{TNT}} = 5.95\times10^{-3}\ \text{mol}\times 227\ \text{g mol}^{-1}
      \approx 1.35\ \text{g}
\]

\[
\boxed{1.35}\ \text{g}
\]

results.question: In the reaction \ce{CO + H2O <=> CO2 + H2}, an initial mixture of \pu{40 mol} of \ce{CO}, \pu{20 mol} of \ce{H2}, and \pu{20 mol} of \ce{CO2} in contact with \pu{40 mol} of steam was allowed to come to equilibrium in a reactor at \pu{1100 K}. At \pu{1100 K} this reaction has a $K_p$ of 0.64. What is the number of moles of \ce{CO2} leaving the reactor after equilibration?
results.llm_output:
The reaction  

\[
\ce{CO + H2O <=> CO2 + H2}
\]

has  

\[
K_{p}=0.64=\frac{p_{\mathrm{CO_2}}\,p_{\mathrm{H_2}}}{p_{\mathrm{CO}}\,p_{\mathrm{H_2O}}}
        =\frac{n_{\mathrm{CO_2}}\,n_{\mathrm{H_2}}}{n_{\mathrm{CO}}\,n_{\mathrm{H_2O}}}
\]

because the total number of gaseous moles does not change (Δn = 0).

Let the extent of reaction be \(\xi\).  
Starting with  

\[
n_{\mathrm{CO},0}=40,\; n_{\mathrm{H_2O},0}=40,\;
n_{\mathrm{CO_2},0}=20,\; n_{\mathrm{H_2},0}=20,
\]

the amounts at equilibrium are  

\[
\begin{aligned}
n_{\mathrm{CO}}      &= 40-\xi,\\
n_{\mathrm{H_2O}}    &= 40-\xi,\\
n_{\mathrm{CO_2}}    &= 20+\xi,\\
n_{\mathrm{H_2}}     &= 20+\xi .
\end{aligned}
\]

Insert these in the expression for \(K_{p}\):

\[
0.64=\frac{(20+\xi)(20+\xi)}{(40-\xi)(40-\xi)}.
\]

Taking the square‑root (all quantities are positive),

\[
20+\xi = 0.8\,(40-\xi)\;\Longrightarrow\;
20+\xi = 32-0.8\xi,
\]

\[
1.8\xi = 12\;\Longrightarrow\;\xi = 6.666\ldots\;\text{mol}.
\]

Thus \(6.67\;\text{mol}\) of \(\ce{CO2}\) are produced as the system reaches equilibrium.  
Since the problem asks for the amount of \(\ce{CO2}\) that leaves the reactor after equilibration, this is precisely the amount formed:

\[
\boxed{6.7\ \text{mol}}.
\]

results.question:
Extraction of gold using sodium cyanide, a very poisonous chemical, causes environmental problems and gives rise to serious public concern about the use of this so called "cyanide process". Thiosulfate leaching of gold has been considered as an alternative. In this process, the main reagent is ammonium thiosulfate, $\left(\mathrm{NH}_{4}\right)_{2} \mathrm{~S}_{2} \mathrm{O}_{3}$, which is relatively non-toxic. Although this process appears to be environmentally benign, the chemistry involved is very complex and needs to be studied thoroughly. The solution used for leaching gold contains $\mathrm{S}_{2} \mathrm{O}_{3}^{2-}, \mathrm{Cu}^{2+}, \mathrm{NH}_{3}$, and dissolved $\mathrm{O}_{2}$. The solution must have a $\mathrm{pH}$ greater than 8.5 to allow free ammonia to be present.

According to the proposed mechanism, a local voltaic micro-cell is formed on the surface of gold particles during the leaching process and operates as follows:

Anode:

$\mathrm{Au}(\mathrm{s})+2 \mathrm{NH}_{3}(\mathrm{aq}) \rightarrow\left[\mathrm{Au}\left(\mathrm{NH}_{3}\right)_{2}\right]^{+}(\mathrm{aq})+e^{-}$

$\left[\mathrm{Au}\left(\mathrm{NH}_{3}\right)_{2}\right]^{+}(a q)+2 \mathrm{~S}_{2} \mathrm{O}_{3}^{2-}(a q) \rightarrow\left[\mathrm{Au}\left(\mathrm{S}_{2} \mathrm{O}_{3}\right)_{2}\right]^{3-}(a q)+2 \mathrm{NH}_{3}(a q)$

Cathode:

$\left[\mathrm{Cu}\left(\mathrm{NH}_{3}\right)_{4}\right]^{2+}(a q)+e^{-} \rightarrow\left[\mathrm{Cu}\left(\mathrm{NH}_{3}\right)_{2}\right]^{+}(a q)+2 \mathrm{NH}_{3}(a q)$

$\left[\mathrm{Cu}\left(\mathrm{NH}_{3}\right)_{2}\right]^{+}(a q)+3 \mathrm{~S}_{2} \mathrm{O}_{3}^{2-}(a q) \rightarrow\left[\mathrm{Cu}\left(\mathrm{S}_{2} \mathrm{O}_{3}\right)_{3}\right]^{5-}(a q)+2 \mathrm{NH}_{3}(a q)$

The formation constants, $K_{f}$, of $\left[\mathrm{Au}\left(\mathrm{NH}_{3}\right)_{2}\right]^{+}$and $\left[\mathrm{Au}\left(\mathrm{S}_{2} \mathrm{O}_{3}\right)_{2}\right]^{3-}$ complexes are $1.00 \cdot 10^{26}$ and $1.00 \cdot 10^{28}$, respectively. Consider a leaching solution in which the equilibrium concentrations of the species are as follows:

$\left[\mathrm{S}_{2} \mathrm{O}_{3}^{2 \cdot}\right]=0.100 ;\left[\mathrm{NH}_{3}\right]=0.100$ and the total concentration of gold $(\mathrm{I})$ species $=$ $5.50 \cdot 10^{-5} \mathrm{~mol} \mathrm{dm}^{-3}$.Calculate the percentage of gold $(I)$ ion that exists in the form of thiosulfate complex.
results.llm_output:
The total dissolved gold concentration is  

\[
C_{\text{Au,total}}=[\text{Au}^+] +[\text{Au(NH}_3)_2]^+ +[\text{Au(S}_2\text{O}_3)_2]^{3-}=5.50\times10^{-5}\ \text{M}
\]

With the formation reactions  

\[
\begin{aligned}
\text{Au}^+ + 2\text{NH}_3 &\rightleftharpoons [\text{Au(NH}_3)_2]^+ ,
\qquad K_{f,1}=1.00\times10^{26}\\[2mm]
\text{Au}^+ + 2\text{S}_2\text{O}_3^{2-} &\rightleftharpoons [\text{Au(S}_2\text{O}_3)_2]^{3-},
\qquad K_{f,2}=1.00\times10^{28}
\end{aligned}
\]

the equilibrium concentrations of the complexes can be expressed in terms of the free gold ion \([ \text{Au}^+ ] = x\):

\[
\begin{aligned}
[\text{Au(NH}_3)_2]^+ &=K_{f,1}\,x\,[\text{NH}_3]^2
      =1.0\times10^{26}\,x\,(0.100)^2
      =1.0\times10^{24}\,x,\\[2mm]
[\text{Au(S}_2\text{O}_3)_2]^{3-}&=K_{f,2}\,x\,[\text{S}_2\text{O}_3^{2-}]^2
      =1.0\times10^{28}\,x\,(0.100)^2
      =1.0\times10^{26}\,x .
\end{aligned}
\]

The mass balance gives  

\[
x\bigl(1+1.0\times10^{24}+1.0\times10^{26}\bigr)=5.50\times10^{-5}\;\text{M}.
\]

Since \(1.0\times10^{26}\) dominates,  

\[
x \approx \frac{5.50\times10^{-5}}{1.01\times10^{26}}
        =5.45\times10^{-31}\ \text{M}.
\]

Hence  

\[
\begin{aligned}
[\text{Au(S}_2\text{O}_3)_2]^{3-} &=1.0\times10^{26}\,x
                                 =5.45\times10^{-5}\ \text{M},\\[2mm]
[\text{Au(NH}_3)_2]^+ &=1.0\times10^{24}\,x
                                 =5.45\times10^{-7}\ \text{M}.
\end{aligned}
\]

The fraction of gold present as the thiosulfate complex is  

\[
\frac{[\text{Au(S}_2\text{O}_3)_2]^{3-}}{C_{\text{Au,total}}}

   =0.990\; .
\]

\[
\boxed{99.0}\% .
\]

Question: """Extraction of gold using sodium cyanide, a very poisonous chemical, causes environmental problems and gives rise to serious public concern about the use of this so called "cyanide process". Thiosulfate leaching of gold has been considered as an alternative. In this process, the main reagent is ammonium thiosulfate, $\left(\mathrm{NH}_{4}\right)_{2} \mathrm{~S}_{2} \mathrm{O}_{3}$, which is relatively non-toxic. Although this process appears to be environmentally benign, the chemistry involved is very complex and needs to be studied thoroughly. The solution used for leaching gold contains $\mathrm{S}_{2} \mathrm{O}_{3}^{2-}, \mathrm{Cu}^{2+}, \mathrm{NH}_{3}$, and dissolved $\mathrm{O}_{2}$. The solution must have a $\mathrm{pH}$ greater than 8.5 to allow free ammonia to be present.

According to the proposed mechanism, a local voltaic micro-cell is formed on the surface of gold particles during the leaching process and operates as follows:

Anode:

$\mathrm{Au}(\mathrm{s})+2 \mathrm{NH}_{3}(\mathrm{aq}) \rightarrow\left[\mathrm{Au}\left(\mathrm{NH}_{3}\right)_{2}\right]^{+}(\mathrm{aq})+e^{-}$

$\left[\mathrm{Au}\left(\mathrm{NH}_{3}\right)_{2}\right]^{+}(a q)+2 \mathrm{~S}_{2} \mathrm{O}_{3}^{2-}(a q) \rightarrow\left[\mathrm{Au}\left(\mathrm{S}_{2} \mathrm{O}_{3}\right)_{2}\right]^{3-}(a q)+2 \mathrm{NH}_{3}(a q)$

Cathode:

$\left[\mathrm{Cu}\left(\mathrm{NH}_{3}\right)_{4}\right]^{2+}(a q)+e^{-} \rightarrow\left[\mathrm{Cu}\left(\mathrm{NH}_{3}\right)_{2}\right]^{+}(a q)+2 \mathrm{NH}_{3}(a q)$

$\left[\mathrm{Cu}\left(\mathrm{NH}_{3}\right)_{2}\right]^{+}(a q)+3 \mathrm{~S}_{2} \mathrm{O}_{3}^{2-}(a q) \rightarrow\left[\mathrm{Cu}\left(\mathrm{S}_{2} \mathrm{O}_{3}\right)_{3}\right]^{5-}(a q)+2 \mathrm{NH}_{3}(a q)$

The formation constants, $K_{f}$, of $\left[\mathrm{Au}\left(\mathrm{NH}_{3}\right)_{2}\right]^{+}$and $\left[\mathrm{Au}\left(\mathrm{S}_{2} \mathrm{O}_{3}\right)_{2}\right]^{3-}$ complexes are $1.00 \cdot 10^{26}$ and $1.00 \cdot 10^{28}$, respectively. Consider a leaching solution in which the equilibrium concentrations of the species are as follows:

$\left[\mathrm{S}_{2} \mathrm{O}_{3}^{2 \cdot}\right]=0.100 ;\left[\mathrm{NH}_{3}\right]=0.100$ and the total concentration of gold $(\mathrm{I})$ species $=$ $5.50 \cdot 10^{-5} \mathrm{~mol} \mathrm{dm}^{-3}$.Calculate the percentage of gold $(I)$ ion that exists in the form of thiosulfate complex."""

Model's reasoning: """The total dissolved gold concentration is  

\[
C_{\text{Au,total}}=[\text{Au}^+] +[\text{Au(NH}_3)_2]^+ +[\text{Au(S}_2\text{O}_3)_2]^{3-}=5.50\times10^{-5}\ \text{M}
\]

With the formation reactions  

\[
\begin{aligned}
\text{Au}^+ + 2\text{NH}_3 &\rightleftharpoons [\text{Au(NH}_3)_2]^+ ,
\qquad K_{f,1}=1.00\times10^{26}\\[2mm]
\text{Au}^+ + 2\text{S}_2\text{O}_3^{2-} &\rightleftharpoons [\text{Au(S}_2\text{O}_3)_2]^{3-},
\qquad K_{f,2}=1.00\times10^{28}
\end{aligned}
\]

the equilibrium concentrations of the complexes can be expressed in terms of the free gold ion \([ \text{Au}^+ ] = x\):

\[
\begin{aligned}
[\text{Au(NH}_3)_2]^+ &=K_{f,1}\,x\,[\text{NH}_3]^2
      =1.0\times10^{26}\,x\,(0.100)^2
      =1.0\times10^{24}\,x,\\[2mm]
[\text{Au(S}_2\text{O}_3)_2]^{3-}&=K_{f,2}\,x\,[\text{S}_2\text{O}_3^{2-}]^2
      =1.0\times10^{28}\,x\,(0.100)^2
      =1.0\times10^{26}\,x .
\end{aligned}
\]

The mass balance gives  

\[
x\bigl(1+1.0\times10^{24}+1.0\times10^{26}\bigr)=5.50\times10^{-5}\;\text{M}.
\]

Since \(1.0\times10^{26}\) dominates,  

\[
x \approx \frac{5.50\times10^{-5}}{1.01\times10^{26}}
        =5.45\times10^{-31}\ \text{M}.
\]

Hence  

\[
\begin{aligned}
[\text{Au(S}_2\text{O}_3)_2]^{3-} &=1.0\times10^{26}\,x
                                 =5.45\times10^{-5}\ \text{M},\\[2mm]
[\text{Au(NH}_3)_2]^+ &=1.0\times10^{24}\,x
                                 =5.45\times10^{-7}\ \text{M}.
\end{aligned}
\]

The fraction of gold present as the thiosulfate complex is  

\[
\frac{[\text{Au(S}_2\text{O}_3)_2]^{3-}}{C_{\text{Au,total}}}
   =\frac{5.45\times10^{-5}}{5.50\times10^{-5}}
   =0.990\; .
\]

Therefore, the percentage of gold(I) that exists as the thiosulfate complex is  

\[
\boxed{99.0}\% .
\]"""

Model's final answer: 99.0

Correct answer: 99

Judgement:

results.question:
In quantum mechanics, the movement of $\pi$ electrons along a neutral chain of conjugated carbon atoms may be modeled using the 'particle in a box' method. The energy of the $\pi$ electrons is given by the following equation:

$$
E_{\mathrm{n}}=\frac{n^{2} h^{2}}{8 m L^{2}}
$$

where $n$ is the quantum number $(n=1,2,3, \ldots), h$ is Planck's constant, $m$ is the mass of electron, and $L$ is the length of the box which may be approximated by $L=(k+2) \times 1.40 \AA$ ( $k$ being the number of conjugated double bonds along the carbon chain in the molecule). A photon with the appropriate wavelength $\lambda$ may promote $a$ m electron from the highest occupied molecular orbital (HOMO) to the lowest unoccupied molecular orbital (LUMO). An approximate semi-empirical formula based on this model which relates the wavelength $\lambda$, to the number of double bonds $k$ and constant $B$ is as follows:

$$
\lambda(\mathrm{nm})=B \times \frac{(k+2)^{2}}{(2 k+1)}
$$Using this semi-empirical formula with $B=65.01 \mathrm{~nm}$ calculate the value of the wavelength $\lambda(\mathrm{nm})$ for octatetraene $\left(\mathrm{CH}_{2}=\mathrm{CH}-\mathrm{CH}=\mathrm{CH}-\mathrm{CH}=\mathrm{CH}-\mathrm{CH}=\mathrm{CH}_{2}\right)$.

results.question:
The second law of thermodynamics is a fundamental law of science. In this problem we consider the thermodynamics of an ideal gas, phase transitions and chemical equilibrium.

3.00 mol of $\mathrm{CO}_{2}$ gas expands isothermically (in thermal contact with the surroundings; temperature $=15^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$ ) against a fixed external pressure of 1.00 bar. The initial and final volumes of the gas are $10.0 \mathrm{dm}^{3}$ and $30.0 \mathrm{dm}^{3}$, respectively.

Estimate the temperature at which the reaction would have an equilibrium constant equal to 1. Ignore slight variations in the thermodynamic data with temperature.
results.llm_output:
The decomposition  

\[
\mathrm{CO_{2}(g)\;\rightleftharpoons\;CO(g)+\tfrac12\,O_{2}(g)}
\]

has a standard Gibbs energy change  

\[
\Delta G^{\circ}= \Delta H^{\circ}-T\Delta S^{\circ}.
\]

At the temperature where the equilibrium constant \(K=1\) we have \(\Delta G^{\circ}=0\); therefore  

\[
T=\frac{\Delta H^{\circ}}{\Delta S^{\circ}} .
\]

Using standard thermodynamic data (at \(298\ \text{K}\))

\[
\begin{aligned}
\Delta H_f^{\circ}(\mathrm{CO_2}) &= -393.5\ \text{kJ mol}^{-1},\\
\Delta H_f^{\circ}(\mathrm{CO})   &= -110.5\ \text{kJ mol}^{-1},\\
\Delta H_f^{\circ}(\mathrm{O_2}) &= 0,
\end{aligned}
\qquad
\begin{aligned}
S^{\circ}(\mathrm{CO_2}) &= 213.6\ \text{J mol}^{-1}\,\text{K}^{-1},\\
S^{\circ}(\mathrm{CO})   &= 197.7\ \text{J mol}^{-1}\,\text{K}^{-1},\\
S^{\circ}(\mathrm{O_2})  &= 205.0\ \text{J mol}^{-1}\,\text{K}^{-1}.
\end{aligned}
\]

The reaction enthalpy and entropy are  

\[
\begin{aligned}
\Delta H^{\circ} &=\bigl[-110.5+0\bigr]-\bigl[-393.5\bigr]
                 = 283.0\ \text{kJ mol}^{-1},\\[4pt]
\Delta S^{\circ} &=\bigl[197.7+\tfrac12(205.0)\bigr]-213.6
                 = 86.6\ \text{J mol}^{-1}\,\text{K}^{-1}.
\end{aligned}
\]

Hence  

\[
T=\frac{283.0\times10^{3}\ \text{J mol}^{-1}}{86.6\ \text{J mol}^{-1}\,\text{K}^{-1}}
  =3.27\times10^{3}\ \text{K}.
\]

\[
\boxed{3.27\times10^{3}}\ \text{K}
\]

results.question:
Dissociating gas cycle

Dinitrogen tetroxide forms an equilibrium mixture with nitrogen dioxide:

$$
\mathrm{N}_{2} \mathrm{O}_{4}(g) \rightleftharpoons 2 \mathrm{NO}_{2}(g)
$$

1.00 mol of $\mathrm{N}_{2} \mathrm{O}_{4}$ was put into an empty vessel with a fixed volume of $24.44 \mathrm{dm}^{3}$. The equilibrium gas pressure at $298 \mathrm{~K}$ was found to be 1.190 bar. When heated to $348 \mathrm{~K}$, the gas pressure increased to its equilibrium value of 1.886 bar.Calculate $\Delta S^{0}$ of the reaction, assuming that they do not change significantly with temperature.
results.llm_output:
The equilibrium constant at each temperature can be obtained from the measured total pressure.  
For the reaction  

\[
\mathrm{N_2O_4(g)}\rightleftharpoons 2\;\mathrm{NO_2(g)}
\]

let the extent of dissociation be \(\xi\).  
Starting with 1 mol N₂O₄ in a volume \(V=24.44\;\text{L}\),

\[
n_{\text{tot}} = \frac{PV}{RT}=1+\xi ,\qquad 
n_{\mathrm{N_2O_4}} = 1-\xi ,\qquad 
n_{\mathrm{NO_2}} = 2\xi .
\]

Hence

\[
K_p = \frac{P_{\mathrm{NO_2}}^{\,2}}{P_{\mathrm{N_2O_4}}}
      =\frac{(y_{\mathrm{NO_2}}P)^2}{y_{\mathrm{N_2O_4}}P}
      =\frac{y_{\mathrm{NO_2}}^{\,2}P}{y_{\mathrm{N_2O_4}}}.
\]

---

### 1.  Equilibrium constants  

Using \(R =0.08314\;\text{L·bar·K}^{-1}\text{mol}^{-1}\):

*At 298 K,  \(P_1=1.190\;\text{bar}\)*  

\[
n_{\text{tot,1}}=\frac{1.190\;(24.44)}{0.08314\;(298)}=1.174
\]
\[
\xi_1 = 0.174,\qquad
y_{\mathrm{NO_2}}=0.297,\; y_{\mathrm{N_2O_4}}=0.703.
\]
\[
K_{p,1}= \frac{(0.297)^2(1.190)}{0.703}=0.149.
\]

*At 348 K,  \(P_2=1.886\;\text{bar}\)*  

\[
n_{\text{tot,2}}=\frac{1.886\;(24.44)}{0.08314\;(348)}=1.595
\]
\[
\xi_2 = 0.595,\qquad
y_{\mathrm{NO_2}}=0.746,\; y_{\mathrm{N_2O_4}}=0.254.
\]
\[
K_{p,2}= \frac{(0.746)^2(1.886)}{0.254}=4.12.
\]

---

### 2.  Van ’t Hoff analysis  

\[
\ln\frac{K_{p,2}}{K_{p,1}} = -\frac{\Delta H^{\circ}}{R}
\left(\frac1{T_2}-\frac1{T_1}\right)
\]

\[
\ln\frac{4.12}{0.149}=3.321,\qquad
\frac1{T_2}-\frac1{T_1}= -4.82\times10^{-4}\;\text{K}^{-1}
\]

\[
\Delta H^{\circ}= \frac{3.321\,R}{4.82\times10^{-4}}
=5.73\times10^{4}\;\text{J mol}^{-1}=57.3\;\text{kJ mol}^{-1}.
\]

---

### 3.  Standard entropy change  

\[
\Delta G^{\circ}= -RT\ln K_p.
\]

At 298 K:

\[
\Delta G^{\circ}_{298}= - (8.314)(298)\ln(0.149)=+4.72\;\text{kJ mol}^{-1}.
\]

Then

\[
\Delta S^{\circ}= \frac{\Delta H^{\circ}-\Delta G^{\circ}}{T}
= \frac{57.3\;-\;4.72}{298}=0.1765\;\text{kJ mol}^{-1}\text{K}^{-1}.
\]

(Using the 348 K data gives the same value.)

\[
\boxed{0.177}\ \text{kJ mol}^{-1}\text{K}^{-1}
\]

results.question:
Lactic acid is formed in the muscles during intense activity (anaerobic metabolism). In the blood, lactic acid is neutralized by reaction with hydrogen carbonate. This will be illustrated by the following calculations:

Lactic acid written as HL is monoprotic, and the acid dissociation constant is $K_{\mathrm{HL}}=1.4 \times 10^{-4}$.

The acid dissociation constants for carbonic acid are: $K_{\mathrm{a} 1}=4.5 \times 10^{-7}$ and $K_{\mathrm{a} 2}=$ $4.7 \times 10^{-11}$. All carbon dioxide remains dissolved during the reactions.

$\mathrm{pH}$ in the blood of a person changed from 7.40 to 7.00 due to lactic acid formed during physical activity. Let an aqueous solution having $\mathrm{pH}=7.40$ and $\left[\mathrm{HCO}_{3}^{-}\right]=$ 0.022 represent blood in the following calculation. How many moles of lactic acid have been added to $1.00 \mathrm{dm}^{3}$ of this solution when its $\mathrm{pH}$ has become 7.00 ?
results.llm_output:
The change in pH from 7.40 to 7.00 is caused by the neutralisation of added lactic acid (HL) by the bicarbonate buffer:

\[
\mathrm{HL}+ \mathrm{HCO_3^-}\rightleftharpoons \mathrm{L^-}+ \mathrm{H_2CO_3}
\]

The equilibrium constant for this reaction is  

\[
K=\frac{K_{\mathrm{HL}}}{K_{a1}}
      =\frac{1.4\times10^{-4}}{4.5\times10^{-7}}
      =3.11\times10^{2}
\]

---

### 1.  Initial composition (pH = 7.40)

\[
pK_{a1}= -\log K_{a1}=6.347
\]

\[
\frac{[\mathrm{HCO_3^-}]}{[\mathrm{H_2CO_3}]}
 =10^{\,pH-pK_{a1}} =10^{7.40-6.347}=11.32
\]

\[
[\mathrm{H_2CO_3}]_0=\frac{0.022}{11.32}=1.94\times10^{-3}\ \text{M}
\]

---

### 2.  Composition after the pH has become 7.00  

At the new pH, the bicarbonate–carbonic‑acid ratio must satisfy

\[
pH = pK_{a1}+ \log\frac{[\mathrm{HCO_3^-}]}{[\mathrm{H_2CO_3}]}
\]

\[
7.00 =6.347+\log\frac{[\mathrm{HCO_3^-}]}{[\mathrm{H_2CO_3}]}
\Longrightarrow 
\frac{[\mathrm{HCO_3^-}]}{[\mathrm{H_2CO_3}]} =10^{0.653}=4.50
\]

Let \(x\) be the amount (mol L\(^{-1}\)) of \(\mathrm{HCO_3^-}\) that reacts with the added lactic acid:

\[
\begin{aligned}
[\mathrm{HCO_3^-}] &=0.022 -x\\[2pt]
[\mathrm{H_2CO_3}] &=1.94\times10^{-3}+x
\end{aligned}
\]

From the ratio above:

\[
\frac{0.022-x}{1.94\times10^{-3}+x}=4.50
\Longrightarrow x =2.41\times10^{-3}\ \text{M}
\]

Thus \(x = 2.41\times10^{-3}\ \text{mol}\) of bicarbonate is converted to carbonic acid.

---

### 3.  Amount of lactic acid added  

If \(n\) mol L\(^{-1}\) of lactic acid is added and \(x\) mol reacts, the equilibrium condition for the neutralisation reaction is

\[
K=\frac{[\mathrm{L^-}][\mathrm{H_2CO_3}]}{[\mathrm{HL}][\mathrm{HCO_3^-}]}
 =\frac{x\,(1.94\times10^{-3}+x)}{(n-x)(0.022-x)} =3.11\times10^{2}
\]

Using the value of \(x\) found above:

\[
\frac{x\,(1.94\times10^{-3}+x)}{(n-x)(0.022-x)} =3.11\times10^{2}
\Longrightarrow n-x =1.7\times10^{-6}\ \text{M}
\]

Hence  

\[
n = x + 1.7\times10^{-6}\approx 2.41\times10^{-3}\ \text{mol}
\]

Because the equilibrium lies far to the right, essentially all the added lactic acid is converted to its conjugate base.

---

\[
\boxed{2.4\times10^{-3}}\ \text{mol}
\]

\]

\]

At the new pH, the bicarbonate–carbonic‑acid ratio must satisfy

\[
pH = pK_{a1}+ \log\frac{[\mathrm{HCO_3^-}]}{[\mathrm{H_2CO_3}]}
\]

\[
7.00 =6.347+\log\frac{[\mathrm{HCO_3^-}]}{[\mathrm{H_2CO_3}]}
\Longrightarrow 
\frac{[\mathrm{HCO_3^-}]}{[\mathrm{H_2CO_3}]} =10^{0.653}=4.50
\]

\[
\begin{aligned}
[\mathrm{HCO_3^-}] &=0.022 -x\\[2pt]
[\mathrm{H_2CO_3}] &=1.94\times10^{-3}+x
\end{aligned}
\]

From the ratio above:

\[
\frac{0.022-x}{1.94\times10^{-3}+x}=4.50
\Longrightarrow x =2.41\times10^{-3}\ \text{M}
\]

Thus \(x = 2.41\times10^{-3}\ \text{mol}\) of bicarbonate is converted to carbonic acid.

---

### 3.  Amount of lactic acid added  

If \(n\) mol L\(^{-1}\) of lactic acid is added and \(x\) mol reacts, the equilibrium condition for the neutralisation reaction is

\[
K=\frac{[\mathrm{L^-}][\mathrm{H_2CO_3}]}{[\mathrm{HL}][\mathrm{HCO_3^-}]}
 =\frac{x\,(1.94\times10^{-3}+x)}{(n-x)(0.022-x)} =3.11\times10^{2}
\]

Using the value of \(x\) found above:

\[
\frac{x\,(1.94\times10^{-3}+x)}{(n-x)(0.022-x)} =3.11\times10^{2}
\Longrightarrow n-x =1.7\times10^{-6}\ \text{M}
\]

Hence  

\[
n = x + 1.7\times10^{-6}\approx 2.41\times10^{-3}\ \text{mol}
\]

Because the equilibrium lies far to the right, essentially all the added lactic acid is converted to its conjugate base.

results.question:
The rechargeable lithium ion battery has been developed in Japan.

The standard electromotive force of the battery is $3.70 \mathrm{~V}$. Assume that the halfreaction at the cathode is

$$
\mathrm{CoO}_{2}+\mathrm{Li}^{+}+\mathrm{e}^{-} \rightarrow \mathrm{LiCoO}_{2}
$$

and the half-reaction at the anode is

$$
\mathrm{LiC}_{6} \rightarrow 6 \mathrm{C}+\mathrm{Li}^{+}+\mathrm{e}^{-} .
$$

The battery cell is constructed using $\mathrm{LiCoO}_{2}$ and graphite (C) as the electrode materials.Calculate the mass of the anode in the completely charged state if $10.00 \mathrm{~g}$ of $\mathrm{LiCoO}_{2}$ and $10.00 \mathrm{~g}$ of graphite (C) are present initially.
results.llm_output:
The overall reaction for charging the cell is  

\[
6\,\mathrm{C}+ \mathrm{LiCoO_2}\;\longrightarrow\; \mathrm{LiC_6}+ \mathrm{CoO_2}
\]

Thus one mole of \(\mathrm{LiCoO_2}\) supplies one mole of \(\mathrm{Li^+}\) that intercalates into six carbon atoms of the anode.

---

**Moles of \(\mathrm{LiCoO_2}\) initially**

\[
M_{\mathrm{LiCoO_2}} = 6.94+58.93+2(15.999)=97.87\;\text{g mol}^{-1}
\]

\[
n_{\mathrm{LiCoO_2}}=\frac{10.00\ \text{g}}{97.87\ \text{g mol}^{-1}}
                =1.022\times10^{-1}\ \text{mol}
\]

**Moles of carbon initially**

\[
M_{\mathrm{C}} = 12.011\ \text{g mol}^{-1}
\]

\[
n_{\mathrm{C}}=\frac{10.00\ \text{g}}{12.011\ \text{g mol}^{-1}}
             =8.33\times10^{-1}\ \text{mol}
\]

The reaction requires 6 mol C per mole of \(\mathrm{LiCoO_2}\); therefore the carbon available ( \(n_{\mathrm{C}}/6 =0.139\ \text{mol}\) ) exceeds the amount of \(\mathrm{LiCoO_2}\) ( \(0.102\ \text{mol}\) ). Hence \(\mathrm{LiCoO_2}\) is the limiting reagent.

---

**Mass of lithium transferred to the anode**

\[
n_{\mathrm{Li}} = n_{\mathrm{LiCoO_2}} = 1.022\times10^{-1}\ \text{mol}
\]

\[
m_{\mathrm{Li}} = n_{\mathrm{Li}}\;M_{\mathrm{Li}}
                = (1.022\times10^{-1}\ \text{mol})(6.94\ \text{g mol}^{-1})
                = 7.09\times10^{-1}\ \text{g}
\]

---

**Mass of the anode in the fully‑charged state**

The anode contains all of the original carbon (10.00 g) plus the lithium that has inserted:

\[
m_{\text{anode}} = 10.00\ \text{g} + 0.709\ \text{g} = 10.709\ \text{g}
\]

Rounded to three significant figures,

\[
\boxed{10.71}\ \text{g}
\]

results.question:
The second law of thermodynamics is a fundamental law of science. In this problem we consider the thermodynamics of an ideal gas, phase transitions and chemical equilibrium.

3.00 mol of $\mathrm{CO}_{2}$ gas expands isothermically (in thermal contact with the surroundings; temperature $=15^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$ ) against a fixed external pressure of 1.00 bar. The initial and final volumes of the gas are $10.0 \mathrm{dm}^{3}$ and $30.0 \mathrm{dm}^{3}$, respectively.

From the data given in the phase diagram, calculate the molar enthalpy change of sublimation of $\mathrm{CO}_{2}$. Write down the formula used.
results.llm_output:
For the sublimation of \(\mathrm{CO_{2}}\) the equilibrium between solid and vapour is described by the Clapeyron (or Clausius–Clapeyron) equation  

\[
\frac{{\rm d}\ln P_{\text{subl}}}{{\rm d}T}= \frac{\Delta H_{\text{subl}}}{RT^{2}} \; .
\]

Because at equilibrium \(\Delta G_{\text{subl}}=0\) one has \(\Delta H_{\text{subl}}=T\Delta S_{\text{subl}}\), so the above expression can be rearranged to give the molar enthalpy of sublimation:

\[
\boxed{\displaystyle 
\Delta H_{\text{subl}} = -\,R\,T^{2}\,\frac{{\rm d}\ln P_{\text{subl}}}{{\rm d}T}}
\]

Using the slope of the sublimation line taken from the CO\(_2\) phase diagram (the change in \(\ln P\) per kelvin between the points \((T_{1}=194.7\;{\rm K},\,P_{1}=1.00\;\text{bar})\) and \((T_{2}=225.0\;{\rm K},\,P_{2}=5.00\;\text{bar})\)), we obtain  

\[
\frac{{\rm d}\ln P}{{\rm d}T}
   \approx \frac{\ln 5.00-\ln 1.00}{225.0-194.7}
   = \frac{1.6094}{30.3}\;{\rm K}^{-1}=0.0531\;{\rm K}^{-1}.
\]

Substituting \(R = 8.314\;\text{J mol}^{-1}\text{K}^{-1}\) and \(T = 195\;\text{K}\) (the sublimation temperature at 1 bar) gives  

\[
\Delta H_{\text{subl}}
   = - (8.314\;\text{J mol}^{-1}\text{K}^{-1})(195\;\text{K})^{2}(0.0531\;\text{K}^{-1})
   \approx 2.52\times10^{4}\;\text{J mol}^{-1}.
\]

\[
\boxed{25.2}\ \text{kJ mol}^{-1}
\]

Question: """Acid-base equilibria in water

A solution $(\mathbf{X}$ ) contains two weak monoprotic acids (those having one acidic proton); HA with the acid dissociation constant of $K_{H A}=1.74 \times 10^{-7}$, and $H B$ with the acid dissociation constant of $K_{H B}=1.34 \times 10^{-7}$. The solution $\mathbf{X}$ has a $\mathrm{pH}$ of 3.75.Titration of $100 \mathrm{~cm}^{3}$ of solution $\mathbf{X}$ requires $100 \mathrm{~cm}^{3}$ of $\mathrm{NaOH}$ solution $\left(c=0.220 \mathrm{~mol} \cdot \mathrm{dm}^{-}{ }^{3}\right)$ for completion. Calculate the initial (total) concentration $\left(\mathrm{mol} \cdot \mathrm{dm}^{-3}\right.$ ) of acid HA in the solution $\mathbf{X}$.

Use reasonable approximations where appropriate. $\left[K_{w}=1.00 \times 10^{-14}\right.$ at $\left.298 \mathrm{~K}\right]$"""

Model's reasoning: """The total amount of base required equals the total amount of acidic protons initially present:

\[
n_{\text{OH}^-}=c_{\text{NaOH}}V_{\text{NaOH}}=0.220\;\text{mol dm}^{-3}\times0.100\;\text{dm}^{3}=0.0220\;\text{mol}
\]

\[
c_{\text{HA}}+c_{\text{HB}}=\frac{n_{\text{OH}^-}}{V_{\text{X}}}= \frac{0.0220}{0.100}=0.220\;\text{mol dm}^{-3}\tag{1}
\]

The measured pH gives

\[
[\mathrm H^+]=10^{-3.75}=1.78\times10^{-4}\;\text{mol dm}^{-3}
\]

For each weak acid \(i\) (\(i=1\) for HA, \(i=2\) for HB)  

\[
\alpha_i=\frac{K_{i}}{[\mathrm H^+] + K_{i}},\qquad 
x_i=c_i\alpha_i
\]

\[
\alpha_{\text{HA}}=\frac{1.74\times10^{-7}}{1.78\times10^{-4}+1.74\times10^{-7}}
          =9.77\times10^{-4}
\]

\[
\alpha_{\text{HB}}=\frac{1.34\times10^{-7}}{1.78\times10^{-4}+1.34\times10^{-7}}
          =7.53\times10^{-4}
\]

Since the total \([\mathrm H^+]\) comes from the dissociation of both acids,

\[
c_{\text{HA}}\alpha_{\text{HA}}+c_{\text{HB}}\alpha_{\text{HB}}=[\mathrm H^+]\tag{2}
\]

Insert \((1)\) (\(c_{\text{HB}}=0.220-c_{\text{HA}}\)) into (2):

\[
c_{\text{HA}}(9.77\times10^{-4})+(0.220-c_{\text{HA}})(7.53\times10^{-4})=1.78\times10^{-4}
\]

\[
c_{\text{HA}}(2.24\times10^{-4})=1.23\times10^{-5}
\qquad\Longrightarrow\qquad
c_{\text{HA}}=5.5\times10^{-2}\;\text{mol dm}^{-3}
\]

\[
\boxed{5.5\times10^{-2}}\;\text{mol dm}^{-3}
\]"""

Model's final answer: 5.5x10^{-2}

Correct answer: 0.053

results.question: The standard deviation in measuring the diameter?d?of a sphere is plus or minus 0.02 centimeter. What is the standard deviation in the calculated volume?V?of the sphere if?\(d = 2.35\)?centimeters?
results.llm_output:
The volume of a sphere expressed in terms of its diameter \(d\) is  

\[
V=\frac{4}{3}\pi\left(\frac{d}{2}\right)^{3}
     =\frac{\pi}{6}\,d^{3}.
\]

For a small uncertainty we propagate the error linearly:

\[
\sigma_V=\left|\frac{dV}{dd}\right|\sigma_d .
\]

Differentiate \(V\) with respect to \(d\):

\[
\frac{dV}{dd}= \frac{\pi}{6}\cdot 3d^{2}= \frac{\pi}{2}\,d^{2}.
\]

Hence  

\[
\sigma_V = \frac{\pi}{2}\,d^{2}\,\sigma_d .
\]

Insert the given numbers \(\;d=2.35\;\text{cm}\) and \(\sigma_d =0.02\;\text{cm}\):

\[
\begin{aligned}
\sigma_V &= \frac{\pi}{2}\,(2.35)^2\,(0.02) \\
         &= \frac{\pi}{2}\,(5.5225)\,(0.02) \\
         &= \pi\,(5.5225)(0.01) \\
         &= 0.055225\,\pi \;\text{cm}^{3}\\
         &\approx 0.173\;\text{cm}^{3}.
\end{aligned}
\]

\[
\boxed{0.17}\ \text{cm}^{3}
\] (rounded to two significant figures, consistent with the given uncertainty).

results.question:
When the fresh-water rivers that run into the Chesapeake Bay flood after heavy rains in the spring, the increase in fresh water in the Bay causes a decrease in the salinity in the areas where oysters grow. The minimum concentration of chloride ions needed in oyster beds for normal growth is $8 \mathrm{ppm}\left(8 \mathrm{mg} \mathrm{dm}^{-3}\right)$.

After one week of heavy rain, the following analysis is done on water from the bay. To a $50.00 \mathrm{~cm}^{3}$ sample of bay water a few drops of a $\mathrm{K}_{2} \mathrm{CrO}_{4}$ solution are added. The sample is then titrated with $16.16 \mathrm{~cm}^{3}$ of a $0.00164 \mathrm{M} \mathrm{AgNO}_{3}$ solution. After $\mathrm{AgNO}_{3}$ solution has been added to the sample a bright red-orange precipitate forms.

The chloride concentration in another $50.00 \mathrm{~cm}^{3}$ sample of bay water was determined by the Volhard method. In this method an excess of $\mathrm{AgNO}_{3}$ is added to the sample. The excess $\mathrm{Ag}^{+}$is titrated with standardized $\mathrm{KSCN}$, forming a precipitate of $\mathrm{AgSCN}$. The endpoint is signalled by the formation of the reddish-brown $\mathrm{FeSCN}^{2+}$ complex that forms when $\mathrm{Ag}^{+}$is depleted. If the excess $\mathrm{Ag}^{+}$from the addition of $50.00 \mathrm{~cm}^{3}$ of $0.00129 \mathrm{M} \mathrm{AgNO}_{3}$ to the water sample required $27.46 \mathrm{~cm}^{3}$ of $1.4110^{-3}$ M KSCN for titration, calculate the concentration of chloride in the bay water sample.

In natural waters with much higher concentration of $\mathrm{Cl}^{-}$, the $\mathrm{Cl}^{-}$can be determined gravimetrically by precipitating the $\mathrm{Cl}^{-}$as $\mathrm{AgCl}$. A complicating feature of this method is the fact that $\mathrm{AgCl}$ is susceptible to photodecomposition as shown by the reaction:

$$
\mathrm{AgCl}(\mathrm{s}) \rightarrow \mathrm{Ag}(\mathrm{s})+1 / 2 \mathrm{Cl}_{2}(\mathrm{~g})
$$

Furthermore, if this photodecomposition occurs in the presence of excess $\mathrm{Ag}^{+}$, the following additional reaction occurs:

$3 \mathrm{Cl}_{2}(\mathrm{~g})+3 \mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{O}+5 \mathrm{Ag}^{+} \rightarrow 5 \mathrm{AgCl}+\mathrm{ClO}_{3}{ }^{-}+6 \mathrm{H}^{+}$

If $0.010 \mathrm{~g}$ of a $3.000 \mathrm{~g}$ sample of $\mathrm{AgCl}$ contaminated with excess $\mathrm{Ag}^{+}$undergoes photodecomposition by the above equations
results.llm_output:
The mass of AgCl that undergoes photodecomposition is  

\[
m = 0.010\;\text{g}
\]

Molar mass of AgCl  

\[
M_{\text{AgCl}} = 107.868\;(\text{Ag}) + 35.453\;(\text{Cl}) = 143.321\;\text{g mol}^{-1}
\]

\[
n_{\text{AgCl}} = \frac{m}{M_{\text{AgCl}}}= \frac{0.010}{143.321}=6.98\times10^{-5}\;\text{mol}
\]

**Step 1 – Photolysis of AgCl**

\[
\text{AgCl(s)} \rightarrow \text{Ag(s)}+\tfrac12\,\text{Cl}_2(g)
\]

Each mole of AgCl gives \( \frac12 \) mol Cl₂, therefore  

\[
n_{\text{Cl}_2}= \frac12 n_{\text{AgCl}} = \frac12(6.98\times10^{-5}) = 3.49\times10^{-5}\;\text{mol}
\]

**Step 2 – Reaction of Cl₂ with excess Ag⁺**

\[
3\text{Cl}_2 + 3\text{H}_2\text{O} + 5\text{Ag}^+ \rightarrow 5\text{AgCl}+ \text{ClO}_3^- + 6\text{H}^+
\]

Three moles of Cl₂ produce one mole of ClO₃⁻, thus  

\[
n_{\text{ClO}_3^-}= \frac{1}{3} n_{\text{Cl}_2}= \frac{1}{3}(3.49\times10^{-5})
               = 1.16\times10^{-5}\;\text{mol}
\]

Assuming the products are finally dissolved in a volume of \(1\;\text{dm}^3\) (1 L), the concentration of chloride‑derived species (here \(\text{ClO}_3^-\)) is

\[
c = \frac{n_{\text{ClO}_3^-}}{V}= 1.16\times10^{-5}\;\text{mol dm}^{-3}
\]

Rounded to two significant figures (as dictated by the mass \(0.010\;\text{g}\)):

\[
\boxed{1.2\times10^{-5}}\;\text{mol dm}^{-3}
\]

results.question:
Acid-base equilibria in water

A solution $(\mathbf{X}$ ) contains two weak monoprotic acids (those having one acidic proton); HA with the acid dissociation constant of $K_{H A}=1.74 \times 10^{-7}$, and $H B$ with the acid dissociation constant of $K_{H B}=1.34 \times 10^{-7}$. The solution $\mathbf{X}$ has a $\mathrm{pH}$ of 3.75.Titration of $100 \mathrm{~cm}^{3}$ of solution $\mathbf{X}$ requires $100 \mathrm{~cm}^{3}$ of $\mathrm{NaOH}$ solution $\left(c=0.220 \mathrm{~mol} \cdot \mathrm{dm}^{-}{ }^{3}\right)$ for completion. Calculate the initial (total) concentration $\left(\mathrm{mol} \cdot \mathrm{dm}^{-3}\right.$ ) of acid HB in the solution $\mathbf{X}$.

Use reasonable approximations where appropriate. $\left[K_{w}=1.00 \times 10^{-14}\right.$ at $\left.298 \mathrm{~K}\right]$
results.llm_output:
The solution \(X\) contains the two weak acids  

\[
\mathrm{HA}\;(K_{a}=1.74\times10^{-7}),\qquad 
\mathrm{HB}\;(K_{b}=1.34\times10^{-7})
\]

with initial molar concentrations \(C_{a}\) and \(C_{b}\), respectively.

---

### 1.  Moles of base required for neutralisation  

\[
n_{\mathrm{OH}^{-}}=c_{\mathrm{NaOH}}V_{\mathrm{NaOH}}
     =(0.220\;\mathrm{mol\,dm^{-3}})(0.100\;\mathrm{L})
     =0.0220\ \mathrm{mol}
\]

Since the acid solution volume is also \(0.100\;\mathrm{L}\),

\[
(C_{a}+C_{b})\times 0.100\;\mathrm{L}=0.0220\ \mathrm{mol}
\Longrightarrow C_{a}+C_{b}=0.220\;\mathrm{mol\,dm^{-3}} \tag{1}
\]

---

### 2.  Relation between \([H^+]\) and the concentrations  

The measured pH is \(3.75\); therefore

\[
[H^{+}]=h=10^{-3.75}=1.78\times10^{-4}\ \mathrm{mol\,dm^{-3}}
\]

For a weak monoprotic acid \( \mathrm{HA}\) the degree of dissociation at a given
\([H^+]=h\) is  

\[
\alpha_{a}=\frac{K_{a}}{h+K_{a}},\qquad 
[{\rm A}^{-}]=\alpha_{a}C_{a}=C_{a}\frac{K_{a}}{h+K_{a}}
\]

Analogously for \(\mathrm{HB}\)

\[
[{\rm B}^{-}]=C_{b}\frac{K_{b}}{h+K_{b}}
\]

Because each dissociated molecule furnishes one proton, the total hydrogen‑ion
concentration is the sum of the contributions:

\[
h=C_{a}\frac{K_{a}}{h+K_{a}}+C_{b}\frac{K_{b}}{h+K_{b}} \tag{2}
\]

---

### 3.  Numerical values  

\[
\frac{K_{a}}{h+K_{a}}=\frac{1.74\times10^{-7}}{1.78\times10^{-4}+1.74\times10^{-7}}
                     =9.76\times10^{-4}
\]

\[
\frac{K_{b}}{h+K_{b}}=\frac{1.34\times10^{-7}}{1.78\times10^{-4}+1.34\times10^{-7}}
                     =7.52\times10^{-4}
\]

Insert these into Eq. (2):

\[
1.78\times10^{-4}=9.76\times10^{-4}C_{a}+7.52\times10^{-4}C_{b}
\]

Together with Eq. (1) (\(C_{a}+C_{b}=0.220\)), solving for \(C_{b}\) gives

\[
C_{b}=0.164\ \text{mol·dm}^{-3},\qquad
C_{a}=0.056\ \text{mol·dm}^{-3}
\]

---

\[
\boxed{0.164}\ \text{mol·dm}^{-3}
\]

results.question:
Acid-base equilibria in water

A solution $(\mathbf{X}$ ) contains two weak monoprotic acids (those having one acidic proton); HA with the acid dissociation constant of $K_{H A}=1.74 \times 10^{-7}$, and $H B$ with the acid dissociation constant of $K_{H B}=1.34 \times 10^{-7}$. The solution $\mathbf{X}$ has a $\mathrm{pH}$ of 3.75.Calculate the $\mathrm{pH}$ of the solution $\mathbf{Y}$ in which the concentration of $\mathrm{NaA}$ initially was $6.00 \times 10^{-2}$ $\mathrm{mol} \cdot \mathrm{dm}^{-3}$ and that of $\mathrm{NaB}$ $4.00 \times 10^{-2} \mathrm{~mol} \cdot \mathrm{dm}^{-3}$.
results.llm_output:
The salts NaA and NaB provide the conjugate bases A⁻ and B⁻ of the weak acids HA and HB.  
For each base we use  

\[
\mathrm{A^- + H_2O \rightleftharpoons HA + OH^-},\qquad 
K_{b,\;A}=\frac{K_w}{K_{a,\;HA}},\qquad 
K_{b,\;B}=\frac{K_w}{K_{a,\;HB}}
\]

with \(K_w = 1.0\times10^{-14}\).

\[
K_{b,\;A}= \frac{1.0\times10^{-14}}{1.74\times10^{-7}}=5.75\times10^{-8},
\qquad
K_{b,\;B}= \frac{1.0\times10^{-14}}{1.34\times10^{-7}}=7.46\times10^{-8}
\]

Let  

\[
x = [\text{OH}^-] \text{ produced from A⁻},\qquad 
y = [\text{OH}^-] \text{ produced from B⁻},\qquad 
S = x+y = [\text{OH}^-]_{\text{total}} .
\]

Because \(K_b\) are very small, the changes in the base concentrations are negligible, so  

\[
K_{b,\;A}\approx\frac{x\,S}{0.060},\qquad 
K_{b,\;B}\approx\frac{y\,S}{0.040}.
\]

Thus  

\[
xS = K_{b,\;A}\,0.060,\qquad 
yS = K_{b,\;B}\,0.040.
\]

Adding the two relations gives  

\[
S^{2}=K_{b,\;A}\,0.060+K_{b,\;B}\,0.040,
\]

\[
S =\sqrt{5.75\times10^{-8}\times0.060
      +7.46\times10^{-8}\times0.040}
   =\sqrt{6.43\times10^{-9}}
   =8.0\times10^{-5}\; \text{M}.
\]

Hence  

\[
[\text{OH}^-]=8.0\times10^{-5}\;\text{M},\qquad 
\mathrm{pOH}= -\log_{10}(8.0\times10^{-5}) = 4.10,
\]

\[
\boxed{\mathrm{pH}=14-\mathrm{pOH}=9.90}.
\]

results.question: Calculate the molar solubility of PbS in a solution in which $\ce{[H_3O^+]}$ is held constant at $3.0\times10^{-4}\ \text{M}$.
results.llm_output:
The dissolution of lead(II) sulfide in acidic solution proceeds via  

\[
\ce{PbS(s) + 2 H^{+} \rightleftharpoons Pb^{2+} + H2S(aq)}
\]

The overall equilibrium constant is  

\[
K = \frac{K_{\text{sp}}}{K_{a1}K_{a2}}
\]

where  

\[
K_{\text{sp}}(\ce{PbS}) = 9.0\times10^{-29},\qquad
K_{a1}(\ce{H2S}) = 1.0\times10^{-7},\qquad
K_{a2}(\ce{H2S}) = 1.0\times10^{-19}.
\]

Thus  

\[
K = \frac{9.0\times10^{-29}}{(1.0\times10^{-7})(1.0\times10^{-19})}
    = 9.0\times10^{-3}.
\]

For the reaction stoichiometry, the solubility \(s\) satisfies  

\[
K = \frac{[\ce{Pb^{2+}}][\ce{H2S}]}{[\ce{H^{+}}]^2}
    = \frac{s^{2}}{[\ce{H^{+}}]^{2}},
\qquad\text{so}\qquad
s = \sqrt{K}\,[\ce{H^{+}}].
\]

With \([\ce{H^{+}}]=3.0\times10^{-4}\,\text{M}\),

\[
s = \sqrt{9.0\times10^{-3}}\;(3.0\times10^{-4})
   = 9.5\times10^{-2}\;(3.0\times10^{-4})
   = 2.9\times10^{-5}\ \text{M}.
\]

\[
\boxed{2.9\times10^{-5}}\ \text{M}
\]

Question: """Calculate the molar solubility of PbS in a solution in which $\ce{[H_3O^+]}$ is held constant at $3.0\times10^{-4}\ \text{M}$."""

Model's reasoning: """The dissolution of lead(II) sulfide in acidic solution proceeds via  

\[
\ce{PbS(s) + 2 H^{+} \rightleftharpoons Pb^{2+} + H2S(aq)}
\]

The overall equilibrium constant is  

\[
K = \frac{K_{\text{sp}}}{K_{a1}K_{a2}}
\]

where  

\[
K_{\text{sp}}(\ce{PbS}) = 9.0\times10^{-29},\qquad
K_{a1}(\ce{H2S}) = 1.0\times10^{-7},\qquad
K_{a2}(\ce{H2S}) = 1.0\times10^{-19}.
\]

Thus  

\[
K = \frac{9.0\times10^{-29}}{(1.0\times10^{-7})(1.0\times10^{-19})}
    = 9.0\times10^{-3}.
\]

For the reaction stoichiometry, the solubility \(s\) satisfies  

\[
K = \frac{[\ce{Pb^{2+}}][\ce{H2S}]}{[\ce{H^{+}}]^2}
    = \frac{s^{2}}{[\ce{H^{+}}]^{2}},
\qquad\text{so}\qquad
s = \sqrt{K}\,[\ce{H^{+}}].
\]

With \([\ce{H^{+}}]=3.0\times10^{-4}\,\text{M}\),

\[
s = \sqrt{9.0\times10^{-3}}\;(3.0\times10^{-4})
   = 9.5\times10^{-2}\;(3.0\times10^{-4})
   = 2.9\times10^{-5}\ \text{M}.
\]

\[
\boxed{2.9\times10^{-5}}\ \text{M}
\]"""

Model's final answer: 2.9x10^{-5}

Correct answer: 1.5e-07

results.question:
The rechargeable lithium ion battery has been developed in Japan.

The standard electromotive force of the battery is $3.70 \mathrm{~V}$. Assume that the halfreaction at the cathode is

$$
\mathrm{CoO}_{2}+\mathrm{Li}^{+}+\mathrm{e}^{-} \rightarrow \mathrm{LiCoO}_{2}
$$

and the half-reaction at the anode is

$$
\mathrm{LiC}_{6} \rightarrow 6 \mathrm{C}+\mathrm{Li}^{+}+\mathrm{e}^{-} .
$$

The battery cell is constructed using $\mathrm{LiCoO}_{2}$ and graphite (C) as the electrode materials.Calculate the mass of the anode in completely discharged state if $10.00 \mathrm{~g}$ of $\mathrm{LiCoO}_{2}$ and $10.00 \mathrm{~g}$ of graphite (C) are present initially.
results.llm_output:
The overall cell reaction, obtained by adding the two half‑reactions, is  

\[
\boxed{\ce{LiCoO2 + 6 C -> CoO2 + LiC6}}
\]

During discharge the lithium ion moves from the \(\ce{LiCoO2}\) electrode to the graphite electrode, producing \(\ce{LiC6}\) on the anode.  
Hence the anode after a complete discharge will contain the product \(\ce{LiC6}\) together with any excess carbon that did not react.

---

### 1. Moles of the reactants  

Molar masses  

\[
\begin{aligned}
M(\ce{LiCoO2}) &= 6.94\;(\text{Li})+58.93\;(\text{Co})+2(15.999)\;(\text{O}) \\
               &= 97.87\;\text{g mol}^{-1} ,\\[2mm]
M(\ce{C}) &= 12.011\;\text{g mol}^{-1},\\[2mm]
M(\ce{LiC6}) &= 6.94 + 6(12.011)=79.01\;\text{g mol}^{-1}.
\end{aligned}
\]

\[
n_{\ce{LiCoO2}}=\frac{10.00\ \text{g}}{97.87\ \text{g mol}^{-1}}=0.1022\ \text{mol}
\]

\[
n_{\ce{C}}=\frac{10.00\ \text{g}}{12.011\ \text{g mol}^{-1}}=0.8326\ \text{mol}
\]

### 2. Limiting reagent  

The reaction consumes 6 mol of carbon per mol of \(\ce{LiCoO2}\).

\[
n_{\ce{C,\,required}} = 6\,n_{\ce{LiCoO2}} = 6(0.1022)=0.613\ \text{mol}
\]

Since \(0.613\ \text{mol}<0.8326\ \text{mol}\), \(\ce{LiCoO2}\) is the limiting reagent.

### 3. Amount of product formed  

\[
n_{\ce{LiC6}} = n_{\ce{LiCoO2}} = 0.1022\ \text{mol}
\]

Mass of \(\ce{LiC6}\) produced  

\[
m_{\ce{LiC6}} = n_{\ce{LiC6}}\,M(\ce{LiC6})
               = 0.1022\,(79.01)=8.06\ \text{g}
\]

### 4. Unreacted carbon  

Carbon consumed  

\[
m_{\ce{C,\,consumed}} = n_{\ce{C,\,required}}\,M(\ce{C})
                      = 0.613\,(12.011)=7.35\ \text{g}
\]

Unreacted carbon  

\[
m_{\ce{C,\,remaining}} = 10.00 - 7.35 = 2.65\ \text{g}
\]

### 5. Mass of the anode after complete discharge  

\[
m_{\text{anode}} = m_{\ce{LiC6}} + m_{\ce{C,\,remaining}}
                  = 8.06\ \text{g} + 2.65\ \text{g}
                  = 10.7\ \text{g}
\]

\[
\boxed{10.7}\ \text{g}
\]

results.question: Calculate the molar solubility of PbS in a solution in which $\ce{[H_3O^+]}$ is held constant at $3.0\times10^{-1}\ \text{M}$.
results.llm_output:
The dissolution equilibrium of lead(II) sulfide is  

\[
\ce{PbS(s) <=> Pb^{2+} + S^{2-}},\qquad K_{sp}= [\ce{Pb^{2+}}][\ce{S^{2-}}].
\]

Let the molar solubility be \(s\;(\mathrm{M})\); then  

\[
[\ce{Pb^{2+}}]=s ,\qquad
\text{total dissolved sulfide}=s=[\ce{S^{2-}}]+[\ce{HS^-}]+[\ce{H2S}].
\]

The acid‑base equilibria for sulfide are  

\[
\begin{aligned}
\ce{HS^- &<=> H^+ + S^{2-}},\qquad K_{a2}=10^{-19},\\
\ce{H2S &<=> H^+ + HS^-},\qquad K_{a1}=10^{-7}.
\end{aligned}
\]

The fractional concentration of \(\ce{S^{2-}}\) in a solution of fixed \([\ce{H^+}]\) is  

\[
\alpha_{2}= \frac{K_{a1}K_{a2}}{[\ce{H^+}]^{2}+K_{a1}[\ce{H^+}]+K_{a1}K_{a2}} .
\]

With \([\ce{H^+}]=3.0\times10^{-1}\ \text{M}\),

\[
\begin{aligned}
[\ce{H^+}]^{2}&=0.09,\\
K_{a1}[\ce{H^+}]&=10^{-7}\times 0.3 = 3\times10^{-8},\\
K_{a1}K_{a2}&=10^{-7}\times10^{-19}=10^{-26}.
\end{aligned}
\]

Since \(0.09\gg 3\times10^{-8},10^{-26}\),

\[
\alpha_{2}\approx\frac{10^{-26}}{0.09}=1.11\times10^{-25}.
\]

The solubility product of lead(II) sulfide is  

\[
K_{sp}=8.0\times10^{-28}.
\]

Because \([\ce{S^{2-}}]=\alpha_{2}s\),

\[
K_{sp}=s\,[\ce{S^{2-}}]=s\,(\alpha_{2}s)=\alpha_{2}s^{2}
\quad\Longrightarrow\quad
s=\sqrt{\frac{K_{sp}}{\alpha_{2}}}.
\]

\[
s=\sqrt{\frac{8.0\times10^{-28}}{1.11\times10^{-25}}}
     =\sqrt{7.2\times10^{-3}}
     =2.68\times10^{-1.5}
     \approx 8.5\times10^{-2}\ \text{M}.
\]

\[
\boxed{8.5\times10^{-2}}\ \text{M}
\]

results.question: What volume of 0.200 M HCl must be added to 500.0 mL of 0.300 M sodium mandelate to produce a buffer solution with a pH of 3.25?
results.llm_output:
Henderson–Hasselbalch equation for the buffer is  

\[
\text{pH}=pK_a+\log\frac{[\text{A}^-]}{[\text{HA}]}
\]

For mandelic acid \(pK_a = 3.41\).  
Initially  

\[
n_{\text{A}^-}=0.300\ \text{times0.500\ \text{L}=0.150\ \text{mol}
\]

Let \(x\) be the moles of \(\text{HCl}\) added.  
Reaction: \(\text{HCl}+\text{A}^- \rightarrow \text{HA}+\text{Cl}^-\)

\[
n_{\text{A}^-}=0.150-x,\qquad n_{\text{HA}}=x
\]

Because the volume term cancels in the ratio,  

\[
3.25 = 3.41 + \log\frac{0.150-x}{x}
\]

\[
\log\frac{0.150-x}{x}= -0.16
\]

\[
\frac{0.150-x}{x}=10^{-0.16}=0.6918
\]

\[
0.150 - x = 0.6918\,x\;\Longrightarrow\;0.150 = 1.6918\,x
\]

\[
x = \frac{0.150}{1.6918}=0.0887\ \text{mol}
\]

The required volume of 0.200 M \(\text{HCl}\) is  

\[
V_{\text{HCl}}=\frac{x}{0.200\ \text{M}}=\frac{0.0887\ \text{mol}}{0.200\ \text{mol L}^{-1}}
=0.443\ \text{L}=443\ \text{mL}
\]

\[
\boxed{443}\ \text{mL}
\]

Question: """Calculate the molar solubility of $\ce{ZnCO_3}$ in a solution buffered to a pH of 7.00."""

Model's reasoning: """The dissolution equilibrium is  

\[
\ce{ZnCO3(s) <=> Zn^{2+} + CO3^{2-}}, \qquad K_{\text{sp}}=[\ce{Zn^{2+}}][\ce{CO3^{2-}}]
\]

Let the total molar solubility be \(s\) (mol L\(^{-1}\)).  
Because each mole of \(\ce{ZnCO3}\) that dissolves furnishes one mole of total inorganic carbon,  

\[
C_{\mathrm T}=s=[\ce{CO3^{2-}}]+[\ce{HCO3^-}]+[\ce{H2CO3}]
\]

At the fixed pH = 7.00, the carbonate speciation is governed by the two acid‑dissociation constants  

\[
K_{a1}=10^{-6.35}=4.47\times10^{-7},\qquad
K_{a2}=10^{-10.33}=4.68\times10^{-11}
\]

The fraction of total carbonate that exists as \(\ce{CO3^{2-}}\) is  

\[
\alpha_{2}= \frac{K_{a1}K_{a2}}
                {[H^+]^{2}+K_{a1}[H^+]+K_{a1}K_{a2}}
\]

With \([H^+]=10^{-7}\,\text{M}\),

\[
\begin{aligned}
[H^+]^{2} &= 1.0\times10^{-14}\\[2pt]
K_{a1}[H^+] &= 4.47\times10^{-7}\times10^{-7}=4.47\times10^{-14}\\[2pt]
K_{a1}K_{a2} &= 4.47\times10^{-7}\times4.68\times10^{-11}=2.09\times10^{-17}
\end{aligned}
\]

\[
\alpha_{2}= \frac{2.09\times10^{-17}}{1.0\times10^{-14}+4.47\times10^{-14}+2.09\times10^{-17}}
           =3.8\times10^{-4}
\]

Because \([\ce{CO3^{2-}}]=\alpha_{2}s\) and \([\ce{Zn^{2+}}]=s\),

\[
K_{\text{sp}} = s\;(\alpha_{2}s)=\alpha_{2}s^{2}
\qquad\Longrightarrow\qquad 
s = \sqrt{\frac{K_{\text{sp}}}{\alpha_{2}}}
\]

The solubility product of zinc carbonate is  

\[
K_{\text{sp}} = 1.5\times10^{-10}
\]

Hence  

\[
s = \sqrt{\frac{1.5\times10^{-10}}{3.8\times10^{-4}}}
   = \sqrt{3.9\times10^{-7}}
   = 6.3\times10^{-4}\;\text{M}
\]

\[
\boxed{6.3\times10^{-4}}\ \text{M}
\]"""

Model's final answer: 6.3x10^{-4}

Correct answer: 0.00051

Judgement:

\[

results.question: Calculate the hydronium ion concentration in a solution that is \(2.0 \times 10^{-4}\,\text{M}\) in aniline hydrochloride, \(\text{C}_6\text{H}_5\text{NH}_3\text{Cl}\).
results.llm_output:
The salt \(\text{C}_6\text{H}_5\text{NH}_3\text{Cl}\) provides the conjugate‑acid \(\text{C}_6\text{H}_5\text{NH}_3^+\) in water:

\[
\text{C}_6\text{H}_5\text{NH}_3^+ \rightleftharpoons \text{C}_6\text{H}_5\text{NH}_2 + \text{H}^+
\]

Its acid dissociation constant is  

\[
K_a = \frac{K_{\mathrm w}}{K_b(\text{aniline})}
\]

For aniline, \(pK_b \approx 9.4\Rightarrow K_b \approx 4.0\times10^{-10}\).  
Thus  

\[
K_a = \frac{1.0\times10^{-14}}{4.0\times10^{-10}} = 2.5\times10^{-5}.
\]

Let the initial concentration of the acid be \(C = 2.0\times10^{-4}\,\text{M}\) and let \(x=[\text{H}^+]\) at equilibrium.  

\[
K_a = \frac{x^{2}}{C-x}\;\;\Longrightarrow\;\;x^{2}+K_a x - K_a C =0.
\]

Solving the quadratic:

\[
x = \frac{-K_a+\sqrt{K_a^{2}+4K_a C}}{2}
    = \frac{-2.5\times10^{-5}+\sqrt{(2.5\times10^{-5})^{2}+4(2.5\times10^{-5})(2.0\times10^{-4})}}{2}
    = 5.9\times10^{-5}\,\text{M}.
\]

Hence the hydronium‑ion concentration is  

\[
\boxed{5.9\times10^{-5}}\ \text{M}.
\]

results.question: A 0.4126 - g sample of primary - standard $\ce{Na_2CO_3}$ was treated with 40.00 mL of dilute perchloric acid. The solution was boiled to remove $\ce{CO_2}$, following which the excess $\ce{HClO_4}$ was back - titrated with 9.20 mL of dilute NaOH. In a separate experiment, it was established that 26.93 mL of the $\ce{HClO_4}$ neutralized the NaOH in a 25.00 - mL portion. Calculate the molarities of the $\ce{HClO_4}$.
results.llm_output:
The moles of \(\ce{Na2CO3}\) in the sample are  

\[
n_{\ce{Na2CO3}}=\frac{0.4126\ \text{g}}{M_{\ce{Na2CO3}}}
              =\frac{0.4126}{105.99}\;\text{mol}=3.894\times10^{-3}\ \text{mol}
\]

Since  

\[
\ce{Na2CO3 + 2 HClO4 -> 2 NaClO4 + H2O + CO2}
\]

the moles of \(\ce{HClO4}\) that react with the carbonate are  

\[
n_{\text{reacted}} = 2\,n_{\ce{Na2CO3}} = 7.788\times10^{-3}\ \text{mol}
\]

Let the molarity of the perchloric acid be \(M_{\ce{HClO4}}\) and that of the NaOH used for the back‑titration be \(M_{\ce{NaOH}}\).

Total moles of \(\ce{HClO4}\) added (40.00 mL)  

\[
n_{\text{total}} = M_{\ce{HClO4}}\,(0.04000\ \text{L})
\]

Moles of excess \(\ce{HClO4}\) titrated with NaOH (9.20 mL)  

\[
n_{\text{excess}} = M_{\ce{NaOH}}\,(0.00920\ \text{L})
\]

Hence  

\[
M_{\ce{NaOH}}(0.00920)=M_{\ce{HClO4}}(0.04000)-7.788\times10^{-3}\qquad (1)
\]

From the separate calibration experiment  

\[
M_{\ce{HClO4}}(0.02693)=M_{\ce{NaOH}}(0.02500)\qquad (2)
\]

Equation (2) gives  

\[
M_{\ce{NaOH}} = M_{\ce{HClO4}}\frac{0.02693}{0.02500}=1.0772\,M_{\ce{HClO4}}
\]

Insert this into (1):

\[
(1.0772\,M_{\ce{HClO4}})(0.00920)=M_{\ce{HClO4}}(0.04000)-7.788\times10^{-3}
\]

\[
M_{\ce{HClO4}}(0.009909)=M_{\ce{HClO4}}(0.04000)-7.788\times10^{-3}
\]

\[
M_{\ce{HClO4}}(0.04000-0.009909)=7.788\times10^{-3}
\]

\[
M_{\ce{HClO4}}(0.030091)=7.788\times10^{-3}
\]

\[
M_{\ce{HClO4}}=\frac{7.788\times10^{-3}}{0.030091}=2.589\times10^{-1}\ \text{M}
\]

Rounded to appropriate significant figures:

\[
\boxed{0.259}\ \text{M}
\]

Question: """A 3.00 - L sample of urban air was bubbled through a solution containing 50.0 mL of 0.0116 M $\ce{Ba(OH)_2}$, which caused the $\ce{CO_2}$ in the sample to precipitate as $\ce{BaCO_3}$. The excess base was back - titrated to a phenolphthalein end point with 23.6 mL of 0.0108 M HCl. Calculate concentration of $\ce{CO_2}$ in the air in parts per million (that is, mL $\ce{CO_2}$/$10^6$ mL air); use 1.98 g/L for the density of $\ce{CO_2}$."""

Model's reasoning: """The moles of \(\ce{Ba(OH)2}\) initially present are  

\[
n_{\text{Ba(OH)2,\,initial}} = (0.0500\;\text{L})(0.0116\;\text{mol L}^{-1}) = 5.80\times10^{-4}\;\text{mol}
\]

Moles of \(\ce{HCl}\) used in the back‑titration:  

\[
n_{\text{HCl}} = (0.0236\;\text{L})(0.0108\;\text{mol L}^{-1}) = 2.55\times10^{-4}\;\text{mol}
\]

Since \( \ce{Ba(OH)2 + 2HCl -> BaCl2 + 2H2O}\),

\[
n_{\text{Ba(OH)2,\,excess}} = \frac{n_{\text{HCl}}}{2}=1.27\times10^{-4}\;\text{mol}
\]

Thus the moles of \(\ce{Ba(OH)2}\) that reacted (and therefore the moles of \(\ce{CO2}\) that precipitated) are  

\[
n_{\ce{CO2}} = n_{\text{Ba(OH)2,\,initial}}-n_{\text{Ba(OH)2,\,excess}}
           = 5.80\times10^{-4} - 1.27\times10^{-4}
           = 4.53\times10^{-4}\;\text{mol}
\]

Mass of this \(\ce{CO2}\):

\[
m_{\ce{CO2}} = n_{\ce{CO2}}\,M_{\ce{CO2}} = (4.53\times10^{-4}\;\text{mol})(44.01\;\text{g mol}^{-1})
            = 1.99\times10^{-2}\;\text{g}
\]

Using the given density of \(\ce{CO2}\) (1.98 g L\(^{-1}\)), its volume is  

\[
V_{\ce{CO2}} = \frac{m_{\ce{CO2}}}{\rho_{\ce{CO2}}}
            = \frac{1.99\times10^{-2}\;\text{g}}{1.98\;\text{g L}^{-1}}
            = 1.01\times10^{-2}\;\text{L}=10.1\;\text{mL}
\]

The air sample volume is \(3.00\;\text{L}=3000\;\text{mL}\).  
Thus the volume fraction of \(\ce{CO2}\) in the air, expressed as ppm ( \(\frac{\text{mL CO}_2}{10^6\text{ mL air}}\) ), is

\[
\text{ppm} = \frac{10.1\;\text{mL}}{3000\;\text{mL}}\times10^{6}
          = 3.36\times10^{3}
\]

\[
\boxed{3.36\times10^{3}}\ \text{ppm}
\]"""

Model's final answer: 3.36x10^{3}

Correct answer: 3350.0

Question: """Chromel is an alloy composed of nickel, iron, and chromium. A 0.6553 - g sample was dissolved and diluted to 250.0 mL. When a 50.00 - mL aliquot of 0.05173 M EDTA was mixed with an equal volume of the diluted sample, all three ions were chelated, and a 5.34 - mL back - titration with 0.06139 M copper(II) was required. The chromium in a second 50.0 - mL aliquot was masked through the addition of hexamethylenetetramine; titration of the Fe and Ni required 36.98 mL of 0.05173 M EDTA. Iron and chromium were masked with pyrophosphate in a third 50.0 - mL aliquot, and the nickel was titrated with 24.53 mL of the EDTA solution. Calculate the percentages of nickel in the alloy."""

Model's reasoning: """The titration data give the amounts of each metal in a 50.0 mL aliquot of the diluted solution.

\[
\begin{aligned}
\text{Total metal (EDTA consumed)} &: 
0.05173\;\mathrm{M}\times 0.05000\;\mathrm{L}
-0.06139\;\mathrm{M}\times 0.00534\;\mathrm{L}=0.0022595\ \text{mol}\\[4pt]
\text{Fe + Ni (second aliquot)} &: 
0.05173\;\mathrm{M}\times 0.03698\;\mathrm{L}=0.001915\ \text{mol}\\[4pt]
\text{Ni (third aliquot)} &: 
0.05173\;\mathrm{M}\times 0.02453\;\mathrm{L}=0.001269\ \text{mol}
\end{aligned}
\]

Hence, for the 50.0 mL aliquot  

\[
\begin{aligned}
n_{\text{Ni}} &=0.001269\ \text{mol}\\
n_{\text{Fe}} &=0.001915-0.001269=0.000646\ \text{mol}\\
n_{\text{Cr}} &=0.0022595-0.001915=0.0003445\ \text{mol}
\end{aligned}
\]

The diluted solution volume is 250 mL, i.e. five times the aliquot volume, so the total moles in the original 0.6553 g sample are  

\[
\begin{aligned}
n_{\text{Ni,total}}&=5(0.001269)=0.006345\ \text{mol}\\
n_{\text{Fe,total}}&=5(0.000646)=0.00323\ \text{mol}\\
n_{\text{Cr,total}}&=5(0.0003445)=0.0017225\ \text{mol}
\end{aligned}
\]

Masses (using atomic weights Ni = 58.693 g mol⁻¹, Fe = 55.845 g mol⁻¹, Cr = 51.996 g mol⁻¹):

\[
\begin{aligned}
m_{\text{Ni}} &=0.006345\;\text{mol}\times58.693\;\frac{\text{g}}{\text{mol}}=0.3724\ \text{g}\\
m_{\text{Fe}} &=0.00323\;\text{mol}\times55.845\;\frac{\text{g}}{\text{mol}}=0.1804\ \text{g}\\
m_{\text{Cr}} &=0.0017225\;\text{mol}\times51.996\;\frac{\text{g}}{\text{mol}}=0.0896\ \text{g}
\end{aligned}
\]

The percent of nickel in the alloy is

\[
\%\,\text{Ni}= \frac{m_{\text{Ni}}}{m_{\text{Ni}}+m_{\text{Fe}}+m_{\text{Cr}}}\times100
= \frac{0.3724}{0.6553}\times100 = 56.8\%
\]

\[
\boxed{56.8}\ \text{Cr}
\]"""

Model's final answer: 56.8

Correct answer: 0.1372

Judgement:

Question: """Chromel is an alloy composed of nickel, iron, and chromium. A 0.6553 - g sample was dissolved and diluted to 250.0 mL. Model's reasoning: """The total moles of metal ions that reacted with EDTA in the first experiment are  

\[
\begin{aligned}
n_{\text{EDTA, added}} &=0.05000\;\text{L}\times0.05173\;\text{M}=2.5865\times10^{-3}\;\text{mol}\\
n_{\text{EDTA, excess}}&=0.00534\;\text{L}\times0.06139\;\text{M}=3.275\times10^{-4}\;\text{mol}\\[2pt]
n_{\text{Metals}}&=n_{\text{EDTA, added}}-n_{\text{EDTA, excess}}
                 =2.2590\times10^{-3}\;\text{mol}
\end{aligned}
\]

Thus in the 50.00 mL aliquot of the diluted solution  

\[
n_{\text{Ni+Fe+Cr}} = 2.2590\times10^{-3}\ \text{mol}
\]

From the second titration (Cr masked)  

\[
n_{\text{Fe+Ni}} = 0.03698\;\text{L}\times0.05173\;\text{M}=1.9152\times10^{-3}\;\text{mol}
\]

From the third titration (Fe and Cr masked)  

\[
n_{\text{Ni}} = 0.02453\;\text{L}\times0.05173\;\text{M}=1.2675\times10^{-3}\;\text{mol}
\]

\[
\begin{aligned}
n_{\text{Fe}} &= n_{\text{Fe+Ni}}-n_{\text{Ni}} = 6.477\times10^{-4}\ \text{mol}\\[2pt]
n_{\text{Cr}} &= n_{\text{Ni+Fe+Cr}}-(n_{\text{Ni}}+n_{\text{Fe}})
               = 3.438\times10^{-4}\ \text{mol}
\end{aligned}
\]

Converting to mass (using atomic weights Cr = 51.996 g mol\(^{-1}\), Fe = 55.845 g mol\(^{-1}\), Ni = 58.693 g mol\(^{-1}\)):

\[

Question: """An unknown cadmium(II) solution was analyzed polarographically by the method of standard additions. A 25.00 - mL sample of the unknown solution produced a diffusion current of 1.86 ??A. Following addition of a 5.00 - mL aliquot of \(2.12\times10^{-3}\ \text{M}\ \ce{Cd^{2+}}\) standard solution to the unknown solution, a diffusion current of 5.27 ??A was produced. Calculate the concentration of \(\ce{Cd^{2+}}\) in the unknown solution."""

Model's reasoning: """The diffusion current is directly proportional to the concentration of cadmium in the solution:

\[
I = k\,C_{\text{final}}
\]

---

### 1.   Concentration of cadmium added (after dilution)

\[
C_{\text{added}} = C_{\text{std}}\;\frac{V_{\text{std}}}{V_{\text{total}}}
               = 2.12\times10^{-3}\;\text{M}\;
                 \frac{5.00\;\text{mL}}{25.00\;\text{mL}+5.00\;\text{mL}}
               = 2.12\times10^{-3}\;\text{M}\;\frac{5}{30}
               = 3.53\times10^{-4}\;\text{M}
\]

### 2.   Dilution of the unknown solution

The original unknown solution (25.00 mL) is diluted to 30.00 mL, so its concentration after addition is

\[
C_{u}' = C_{u}\,\frac{25.00}{30.00}= \frac{5}{6}\,C_{u}
\]

### 3.   Relating currents to concentrations  

From the first measurement (no standard added)

\[
I_{1}=k\left(\frac{5}{6}C_{u}\right)=1.86\;\mu\text{A}
\tag{1}
\]

From the second measurement (standard added)

\[
I_{2}=k\left(\frac{5}{6}C_{u}+C_{\text{added}}\right)=5.27\;\mu\text{A}
\tag{2}
\]

Divide (2) by (1) to eliminate \(k\):

\[
\frac{5.27}{1.86}= 
\frac{ \frac{5}{6}C_{u}+C_{\text{added}}}{\frac{5}{6}C_{u}}
=1+\frac{C_{\text{added}}}{\frac{5}{6}C_{u}}
\]

\[
\frac{5.27}{1.86}=1+\frac{6}{5}\,\frac{C_{\text{added}}}{C_{u}}
\]

Solve for \(C_{u}\):

\[
\frac{6}{5}\,\frac{C_{\text{added}}}{C_{u}}=
\frac{5.27}{1.86}-1
\]

\[
\frac{C_{\text{added}}}{C_{u}}=
\frac{5}{6}\left(\frac{5.27}{1.86}-1\right)
\]

\[
C_{u}= \frac{C_{\text{added}}}
           {\dfrac{5}{6}\left(\dfrac{5.27}{1.86}-1\right)}
\]

Insert \(C_{\text{added}} = 3.53\times10^{-4}\;\text{M}\):

\[
C_{u}= \frac{3.53\times10^{-4}}
           {\,1.528\;}
       = 2.3\times10^{-4}\;\text{M}
\]

---

\[
\boxed{2.31\times10^{-4}}\ \text{M}
\]"""

Model's final answer: 2.31x10^{-4}

Correct answer: 0.000177

Question: """Chromel is an alloy composed of nickel, iron, and chromium. A 0.6553 - g sample was dissolved and diluted to 250.0 mL. When a 50.00 - mL aliquot of 0.05173 M EDTA was mixed with an equal volume of the diluted sample, all three ions were chelated, and a 5.34 - mL back - titration with 0.06139 M copper(II) was required. The chromium in a second 50.0 - mL aliquot was masked through the addition of hexamethylenetetramine; titration of the Fe and Ni required 36.98 mL of 0.05173 M EDTA. Iron and chromium were masked with pyrophosphate in a third 50.0 - mL aliquot, and the nickel was titrated with 24.53 mL of the EDTA solution. Calculate the percentages of iron in the alloy."""

Model's reasoning: """The first titration gives the total moles of metal in the 50 mL aliquot:

\[
\begin{aligned}
n_{\text{EDTA,added}} &=0.05173\;\text{M}\times0.05000\;\text{L}=2.5865\times10^{-3}\;\text{mol}\\
n_{\text{EDTA,excess}}&=0.06139\;\text{M}\times0.00534\;\text{L}=3.2762\times10^{-4}\;\text{mol}\\
n_{\text{metal (50 mL)}}&=n_{\text{EDTA,added}}-n_{\text{EDTA,excess}}
=2.2589\times10^{-3}\;\text{mol}
\end{aligned}
\]

The total solution volume is 250 mL, so the total moles of metal in the whole sample are

\[
n_{\text{M,total}}=5\times2.2589\times10^{-3}=1.1294\times10^{-2}\;\text{mol}
\]

Second titration (Cr masked) gives Fe + Ni in a 50 mL aliquot:

\[
n_{\text{Fe+Ni (50 mL)}}=0.05173\;\text{M}\times0.03698\;\text{L}=1.9130\times10^{-3}\;\text{mol}
\]
\[
n_{\text{Fe+Ni,total}}=5\times1.9130\times10^{-3}=9.5650\times10^{-3}\;\text{mol}
\]

Third titration (Fe and Cr masked) gives Ni alone:

\[
n_{\text{Ni (50 mL)}}=0.05173\;\text{M}\times0.02453\;\text{L}=1.2689\times10^{-3}\;\text{mol}
\]
\[
n_{\text{Ni,total}}=5\times1.2689\times10^{-3}=6.3445\times10^{-3}\;\text{mol}
\]

Thus

\[
\begin{aligned}
n_{\text{Fe,total}} &= n_{\text{Fe+Ni,total}}-n_{\text{Ni,total}} \\
&=9.5650\times10^{-3}-6.3445\times10^{-3}=3.2205\times10^{-3}\;\text{mol}
\end{aligned}
\]

Mass of Fe in the alloy:

\[
m_{\text{Fe}} = n_{\text{Fe,total}}\times M_{\text{Fe}}
=3.2205\times10^{-3}\;\text{mol}\times55.845\;\frac{\text{g}}{\text{mol}}
=0.17985\;\text{g}
\]

Percentage of iron in the original 0.6553‑g sample:

\[
\%\,\text{Fe}= \frac{0.17985\;\text{g}}{0.6553\;\text{g}}\times100
= 27.46\%
\]

\[
\boxed{27.46}\ \text{Fe}
\]"""

Model's final answer: 27.46

Correct answer: 0.2744

Judgement:

results.question: Poly(lactic acid) (PLA) can be broken down enzymatically to lactic acid monomer and compound B (a dimer of lactic acid). A plastic sample degraded to \pu{1.044 g}, and titration showed it needed \pu{19.40 cm^3} of \pu{0.100 mol dm^{-3}} \ce{NaOH} to neutralize. What is the number of moles of acid in the sample?
results.llm_output:
The neutralisation reaction is  

\[
\ce{HA + NaOH -> NaA + H2O}
\]

Each mole of acid (whether lactic‑acid monomer or the dimer, which contains one free –COOH group) consumes one mole of \(\ce{NaOH}\).

\[
\begin{aligned}
V_{\ce{NaOH}} &= 19.40\ \text{cm}^{3}=0.01940\ \text{L}\\[2mm]
c_{\ce{NaOH}} &= 0.100\ \text{mol L}^{-1}\\[2mm]
n_{\ce{NaOH}} &= c_{\ce{NaOH}} \times V_{\ce{NaOH}}\\
                &= 0.100\ \frac{\text{mol}}{\text{L}}\times 0.01940\ \text{L}\\
                &= 1.94\times10^{-3}\ \text{mol}
\end{aligned}
\]

Since the stoichiometry is 1 : 1, the number of moles of acidic groups present in the degraded sample is the same as the moles of \(\ce{NaOH}\) used.

\[
\boxed{1.94\times10^{-3}}\ \text{mol}
\]

results.question: Molar absorptivity data for the cobalt and nickel complexes with 2,3 - quinoxalinedithiol are $\varepsilon_{\ce{Co}} = 36,400$ and $\varepsilon_{\ce{Ni}} = 5520$ at 510 nm and $\varepsilon_{\ce{Co}} = 1240$ and $\varepsilon_{\ce{Ni}} = 17,500$ at 656 nm. A 0.425 - g sample was dissolved and diluted to 50.0 mL. A 25.0 - mL aliquot was treated to eliminate interferences; after addition of 2,3 - quinoxalinedithiol, the volume was adjusted to 50.0 mL. This solution had an absorbance of 0.446 at 510 nm and 0.326 at 656 nm in a 1.00 - cm cell. Calculate the concentration in parts per million of nickel in the sample.
results.llm_output:
The absorbances at the two wavelengths are described by  

\[
\begin{cases}
A_{510}= \varepsilon_{\text{Co},510}\,c_{\text{Co}}+\varepsilon_{\text{Ni},510}\,c_{\text{Ni}}\\[4pt]
A_{656}= \varepsilon_{\text{Co},656}\,c_{\text{Co}}+\varepsilon_{\text{Ni},656}\,c_{\text{Ni}}
\end{cases}
\]

with \(l=1\;\text{cm}\).  

Insert the given molar absorptivities (M\(^{-1}\,{\rm cm}^{-1}\)) and absorbances:

\[
\begin{cases}
0.446 = 36400\,c_{\text{Co}} + 5520\,c_{\text{Ni}}\\[4pt]
0.326 = 1240\,c_{\text{Co}} + 17500\,c_{\text{Ni}}
\end{cases}
\]

Solving the simultaneous equations gives  

\[
c_{\text{Ni}} = 1.80\times10^{-5}\;{\rm mol\,L^{-1}}, \qquad
c_{\text{Co}} = 9.5\times10^{-6}\;{\rm mol\,L^{-1}} .
\]

The amount of Ni in the final 50 mL solution is  

\[
n_{\text{Ni}} = c_{\text{Ni}}V = (1.80\times10^{-5}\,\text{mol L}^{-1})(0.050\;\text{L})
              = 9.0\times10^{-7}\;\text{mol}.
\]

Mass of Ni (M\(_\text{Ni}=58.69\;\text{g mol}^{-1}\)):

\[
m_{\text{Ni}} = n_{\text{Ni}}M_{\text{Ni}} = (9.0\times10^{-7})(58.69)
               = 5.27\times10^{-5}\;\text{g}=5.27\times10^{-2}\;\text{mg}.
\]

This corresponds to the Ni present in the 25 mL aliquot taken from the original 50 mL digest; therefore the total Ni in the whole digest is twice this amount:

\[
m_{\text{Ni,total}} = 2(5.27\times10^{-2}\;\text{mg}) = 1.05\times10^{-1}\;\text{mg}.
\]

The original sample weighed \(0.425\;\text{g}\).  Parts‑per‑million (mass basis) is

\[
\text{Ni(ppm)} = \frac{m_{\text{Ni,total}}\,(\text{mg})}{m_{\text{sample}}\,(\text{g})}\times 1000
               = \frac{0.105\;\text{mg}}{0.425\;\text{g}}\times 1000
               = 2.48\times10^{2}\;\text{ppm}.
\]

\[
\boxed{2.48\times10^{2}}\;\text{Ni(ppm)}
\]
